questions.text: The region marked corresponds to the surface marking for which of the following structures:-
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Right atrium: The marked region corresponds to the surface marking for the right atrium, which aligns with the right sternal border. 

Incorrect Option:

Option A - The thoracic duct in the posterior mediastinum drains lymph from the lower and left upper body into the venous system but isn't represented by the marked region on the image.

Option C - Inferomedial bronchopulmonary segments are specific regions within the lungs. They are not related to the region marked on the image, which is external to the lungs.

Option D - The hilum is where blood vessels, nerves, and bronchi enter or exit an organ, like the hila of the lungs. However, the marked region on the image isn't the hilum.

questions.text: The action of the muscle attached to the marked area?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C : The action of the muscle attached to the marked area is abduction.

The muscle attached to the lateral surface of the greater trochanter is the gluteus Medius muscle. It plays a crucial role in the abduction of the hip joint. Abduction refers to the movement of a body part away from the midline of the body. In the case of the hip joint, abduction involves moving the leg away from the body's midline, out to the side.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Flexion refers to bending or decreasing the angle between two body parts. The action of the gluteus Medius muscle is not primarily related to flexion.

Option B: Adduction refers to the movement of a body part towards the midline of the body. The gluteus Medius muscle is not directly involved in adduction but rather acts as an antagonist to the adductor muscles.

Option D: Extension refers to straightening or increasing the angle between two body parts. The gluteus Medius muscle does not primarily contribute to extension but rather to abduction.

questions.text: Which finger possesses two dorsal interossei muscles among the following options?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C: The middle finger has two dorsal interossei muscles.

The dorsal interossei muscles are a group of muscles located in the hand between the metacarpal bones. They play a role in finger abduction, which is the movement of the fingers away from the midline of the hand. The middle finger is the only finger that has two dorsal interossei muscles.

Incorrect Option:

Option A: The index finger has only one dorsal interosseous muscle.

Option B: The little finger, also known as the Pinky finger, has only one dorsal interosseous muscle.

Option D: The ring finger has only one dorsal interosseous muscle.

questions.text: Which muscle among the following is not innervated by the structure labeled as A?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Superior oblique:

Superior oblique muscle is not supplied by the structure marked A, which is the oculomotor nerve.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - The oculomotor nerve innervates the superior rectus muscle, which is responsible for elevating the eye and medially rotating it.

Option C - The oculomotor nerve innervates the medial rectus muscle, which is responsible for adducting the eye (moving it inward towards the midline).

Option D - The oculomotor nerve innervates the LPS muscle, which is responsible for elevating the upper eyelid.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the levator ani muscles is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 

Option D: The wrong statement regarding the levator ani muscles is that they are attached to the pelvic brim. The levator ani muscles are not attached to the pelvic brim. Instead, they originate from various bony structures in the pelvis, including the pubis, ischial spine, and tendinous arch of the pelvic fascia. The muscles then converge and attach to the coccyx and the anococcygeal raphe.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A: The statement that the levator ani muscles support pelvic viscera is correct. The levator ani muscles form a muscular sling within the pelvis and provide support to the pelvic organs, including the bladder, uterus, and rectum.

Option B: The statement that the levator ani muscles converge downwards and medially is correct. The muscle fibers of the levator ani muscles come together and run in a downward and medial direction towards the midline of the pelvis.

Option C: The statement that the levator ani muscles consist of the iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus muscles is correct. The levator ani muscles are composed of three main parts: the pubococcygeus, iliococcygeus, and puborectalis muscles. The iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus muscles are two of the components of the levator ani muscle group.

questions.text: What are the effects of a Supracondylar fracture ?

choices.text: Loss of sensation of the nail of index finger
Loss of sensation at the tip of radial tubercle
Loss of sensation of the 4th interdigital cleft

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A. Loss of sensation of the nail of the index finger: Ape thumb deformity; Benediction hand; Weakness in wrist flexion; hand deviates to ulnar side on flexion; flexion of index and middle finger is lost; anterior abduction, opposition and flexion of thumb is compromised; sensory loss on the lateral 3 & ½ fingers; difficulty in making an 'O' with thumb and index finger.

 

Incorrect Option:

Option B. Hypothenar muscles wasting: Lesion of the median nerve wouldn't directly cause wasting or weakness of the hypothenar muscles, as they're innervated by the ulnar nerve, not the median nerve.

Option C. Loss of sensation at the tip of the radial tubercle: A median nerve lesion wouldn't cause loss of sensation at the radial tubercle tip, as its innervation comes from radial nerve branches, not the median nerve.

Option D. Loss of sensation of the 4th interdigital cleft: A median nerve lesion wouldn't lead to sensory loss in the 4th interdigital cleft since its innervation comes from the ulnar nerve, not the median nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following structures given below is related to the structure highlighted (red) in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A

Option A: a. Pudendal nerve: The pudendal nerve is the correct option. The pudendal nerve is a nerve that arises from the sacral plexus and provides sensory and motor innervation to the perineum, including the external genitalia and the anus. The ischial spine is an important landmark in the pelvis, and the pudendal nerve passes posterior to the ischial spine during its course.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Sciatic nerve: The sciatic nerve is an incorrect option. The sciatic nerve is the largest nerve in the body and arises from the sacral plexus. It runs down the posterior thigh and does not directly pass through or relate to the ischial spine.

Option C: Obturator nerve: The obturator nerve is an incorrect option. The obturator nerve arises from the lumbar plexus and provides sensory and motor innervation to the medial compartment of the thigh. It does not have a direct relationship with the ischial spine.

Option D: Femoral nerve: Option D is not explained in the initial question. However, the femoral nerve is an incorrect option. The femoral nerve arises from the lumbar plexus and provides sensory and motor innervation to the anterior thigh. It does not have a direct relationship with the ischial spine.

questions.text: Marked structure is derived from the ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Endocardial cushions:

The endocardial cushions play a crucial role in the development of the heart's septa and valves. They contribute to the formation of various structures, including the atrial septum, ventricular septum, and the atrioventricular (AV) valves. Therefore, it is correct to say that the marked structure is derived from the endocardial cushions.

Incorrect Option:

Option B - Septum primum: During embryonic development, the septum primum grows downward from the roof of the primitive atrium but doesn't directly form the marked structure.

Option C - Left venous valve: The left venous valve regulates blood flow from the coronary sinus in the right atrium but doesn't contribute to the marked structure's formation.

Option D - Bulbous venosus: The bulbous venosus, part of the embryonic heart tube, helps form the right ventricle but doesn't directly create the marked structure.

questions.text: Which of the following does not supply the marked structure?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Diagonal artery:

The diagonal artery does not supply the marked structure (right ventricle). The diagonal artery is a branch of the left anterior descending artery and primarily supplies the left ventricle and the anterior walls of the heart.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - The right coronary artery supplies blood to the right ventricle, which is the marked structure. It's one of the main arteries responsible for nourishing the right side of the heart..

Option B - The anterior interventricular artery, a branch of the left coronary artery, supplies blood to the interventricular septum and front walls of both ventricles, including the right ventricle.

Option C - The marginal artery, a branch of the right coronary artery, supplies blood to the right ventricle. It runs along the heart's right border, providing blood to the right ventricle's lateral wall.

questions.text: Which layer is indicated in the provided histological section?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Inner plexiform layer:

  • The inner plexiform layer is the layer in the retina where synapses occur between bipolar cells, amacrine cells, and ganglion cells.
  • It is responsible for processing and integrating visual signals before transmitting them to the ganglion cell layer.

Incorrect Options - A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: Child presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be Zellweger syndrome. Which among the following accumulates in brain in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option c. Long chain fatty acid: In Zellweger syndrome, impaired peroxisomal function leads to the accumulation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFAs), including those with 26 to 38 carbon atoms. These VLCFAs cannot be metabolized properly in the absence of functional peroxisomes, resulting in their accumulation in various tissues, including the brain.

 

Incorrect option:

Option a. Glucose: Glucose is a sugar and is not specifically associated with the accumulation seen in Zellweger syndrome. Therefore, glucose does not accumulate in the brain in this condition.

Option b. Lactic acid: Lactic acid is produced during anaerobic metabolism and can accumulate in certain metabolic disorders. However, it is not specifically associated with Zellweger syndrome. Therefore, lactic acid does not accumulate in the brain in this condition.

Optiond. Triglycerides: Triglycerides are a type of fat that is composed of three fatty acid chains attached to a glycerol molecule. While lipid metabolism is disrupted in Zellweger syndrome, the specific accumulation of triglycerides in the brain is not a characteristic feature of this condition. Therefore, triglycerides do not accumulate in the brain in Zellweger syndrome.

questions.text: What is chimeric DNA used for?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Organ transplantation:

  • Chimeric DNA can be used in organ transplantation to analyze compatibility between the donor and recipient. By comparing certain genetic markers, such as human leukocyte antigen (HLA) compatibility, chimeric DNA analysis helps determine the likelihood of a successful organ transplant. 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Paternity test: Paternity tests typically involve analyzing DNA samples from the alleged father, child, and mother (if available) to determine biological parentage. Chimeric DNA is not specifically used for paternity testing.

Option B - Maternity test: Similar to paternity tests, maternity tests involve analyzing DNA samples to determine biological parentage. Chimeric DNA is not specifically used for maternity testing.

Option C- Personal identification: Personal identification can be done using DNA analysis techniques such as DNA fingerprinting or forensic DNA profiling. Chimeric DNA is not specifically used for personal identification.

questions.text: Which of the following shows functional assessment of B1 deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A. RBC Transketolase: This test assesses the activity of the enzyme transketolase, which requires thiamine (vitamin B1) as a cofactor. A decreased activity indicates a deficiency of thiamine.

 

Incorrect Option:

Option B. RBC glutathione reductase: This test measures the activity of the enzyme glutathione reductase, which is not specifically related to thiamine deficiency. It is used to evaluate the function of the glutathione system and is not directly indicative of B1 deficiency.

Option C. Serum thiamine levels: This test directly measures the levels of thiamine in the blood. Low serum thiamine levels may suggest a deficiency, but it is not a functional assessment of B1 deficiency.

OptionD. RBC glutathione peroxidase: This test measures the activity of the enzyme glutathione peroxidase, which is not specifically related to thiamine deficiency. It is involved in the detoxification of reactive oxygen species and is not directly indicative of B1 deficiency.

questions.text: The graph shown below is the titration curve of a biochemical compound. Which of the following statement is true?

choices.text: The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B
The points A and B represent the range of maximum ionization of the amine and carboxyl group
The compound has three ionizable side chains
The compound has one ionizable group

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B

Option A - The statement "The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B" is true. Points A and B on the titration curve correspond to the region where the compound acts as a buffer. In this region, the compound can effectively resist changes in pH by accepting or donating protons.

 

Incorrect Option:

Option B - The statement "The points A and B represent the range of maximum ionization of the amine and carboxyl group" is incorrect. Points A and B do not represent the maximum ionization of the amine and carboxyl groups specifically. They represent the region of maximum buffering capacity, but the overall ionization of the amine and carboxyl groups can occur over a broader pH range.

Option C - The statement "The compound has three ionizable side chains" is incorrect. Glycine, being a simple amino acid, does not have any ionizable side chains. It has a carboxyl group (COOH) and an amine group (NH2), both of which can undergo ionization.

Option D - The statement "The compound has one ionizable group" is incorrect. Glycine has two ionizable groups: the carboxyl group (COOH) and the amine group (NH2). These groups can gain or lose protons (H+) depending on the pH of the solution.

questions.text: What is the mechanism through which gene repair occurs when CRISPR-Cas9 is utilized?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ):

  • This is the correct option. NHEJ is a DNA repair pathway that repairs double-strand breaks (DSBs) by directly ligating the broken DNA ends without requiring a homologous template.
  • CRISPR-Cas9 can induce targeted DSBs at specific sites in the genome, and NHEJ is often utilized to repair these breaks. However, NHEJ can introduce small insertions or deletions (indels) during the repair process, which may result in gene disruptions or mutations.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Base excision: Base excision repair (BER) is a DNA repair mechanism that primarily corrects small base lesions, such as single base changes or small chemical modifications. Option C - Homologous End Joining (HEJ) or Homology-Directed Repair (HDR): HDR is a DNA repair pathway that uses a homologous DNA template to repair DSBs, resulting in precise DNA sequence changes.

Option D - Mismatch repair: Mismatch repair is a DNA repair mechanism that corrects errors in DNA replication, such as mismatches or small insertion/deletion loops.

questions.text: The catalytic efficiency of enzyme is best expressed by which of the following kinetic constant:-
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Kcat/Km

  • This option represents the ratio of the turnover number (Kcat) to the Michaelis constant (Km).
  • The turnover number (Kcat) is a measure of how many substrate molecules an enzyme can convert to product per unit of time when the enzyme is saturated with the substrate.
  • The Michaelis constant (Km) represents the substrate concentration at which the reaction rate is half of its maximum.
  • The ratio Kcat/Km provides a measure of how efficient the enzyme is at converting substrate to product, taking into account both the rate of the reaction (Kcat) and the affinity of the enzyme for the substrate (Km). A higher Kcat/Km value indicates a more efficient enzyme.

Incorrect Option:

Option B - Km/Kcat The ratio Km/Kcat does not provide a meaningful measure of catalytic efficiency, as it would yield a value that is the reciprocal of Kcat/Km. It does not accurately represent the efficiency of the enzyme.

Option C - Km/ka The rate constant for the association of the enzyme and substrate (ka) is not directly related to catalytic efficiency. Therefore, this option does not express the catalytic efficiency of the enzyme accurately.

Option D - Ka/Km Similarly to option C, the rate constant for the association of the enzyme and substrate (ka) is not directly related to catalytic efficiency. Hence, this option does not accurately express the catalytic efficiency of the enzyme.

questions.text: A young boy from high altitude came with fever and weakness and had the following reports- Hemoglobin 17 g%, TLC is 21,000 with neutrophils 25, lymphocytes 30, eosinophils 5, myelocytes and metamyelocytes 40 in peripheral smear. Next step in the investigation should be:

choices.text: Bone marrow biopsy with reticulin stain

questions.solution:
Correct Option C

  • The clinical presentation of a young boy from a high altitude with fever, weakness, high hemoglobin, and increased TLC with a predominance of neutrophils and myeloid cells suggests reactive or secondary polycythemia.
  • In this context, it is important to assess the erythropoietin levels.
  • In reactive polycythemia, EPO levels are expected to be low or normal due to an appropriate physiological response to hypoxia.
  • If EPO levels are elevated, it would raise concerns for primary polycythemia such as polycythemia vera or an EPO-secreting tumor

Incorrect Option:

Option A: Philadelphia chromosome is a genetic abnormality associated with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), a type of blood cancer. However, the given clinical presentation with high hemoglobin, increased total leukocyte count (TLC), and presence of myelocytes and metamyelocytes in the peripheral smear does not suggest CML. Therefore, investigating the Philadelphia chromosome is not indicated in this case.

Option B: JAK mutation refers to mutations in the Janus kinase (JAK) genes, which can be seen in certain myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPNs) such as polycythemia vera, essential thrombocythemia, and primary myelofibrosis. While the peripheral smear findings of increased myelocytes and metamyelocytes may raise suspicion for an MPN, the high haemoglobin level and low leukocyte count are not consistent with these disorders. Therefore, investigating JAK mutation is not the most appropriate next step.

Option D: Bone marrow biopsy with reticulin stain is a more invasive and specific investigation that may be considered if the initial workup, including EPO levels, is inconclusive or if there are additional findings suggestive of a myeloproliferative disorder or myelodysplastic syndrome. However, in the given clinical scenario of a young boy with high haemoglobin, increased TLC with myeloid predominance, and weakness, the more appropriate initial step is to assess EPO levels before proceeding to a bone marrow biopsy.

Therefore, the correct option is C, to measure the erythropoietin levels.

questions.text: The attachment of Eukaryotic mRNA to the ribosome is mediated through
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Guanyl Cap:

  • The guanyl cap, also known as the 5' cap, is a modified nucleotide structure added to the 5' end of eukaryotic mRNA molecules. It consists of a guanine nucleotide linked to the mRNA through a unique 5' to 5' triphosphate bond.
  • The guanyl cap plays a crucial role in the attachment of mRNA to the ribosome during translation initiation. It helps in recognition by the ribosome and initiation factors, facilitating the binding of mRNA to the ribosome for protein synthesis.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Poly A tail The poly A tail is a stretch of adenine nucleotides added to the 3' end of eukaryotic mRNA molecules. It plays a role in mRNA stability and regulation but is not directly involved in the attachment of mRNA to the ribosome.

Option B - tRNA Transfer RNA (tRNA) molecules are involved in protein synthesis but not in the direct attachment of mRNA to the ribosome.

Option D - Shine-Dalgarno Sequence The Shine-Dalgarno sequence is a specific nucleotide sequence found in prokaryotic mRNA molecules. It plays a role in the initiation of translation in prokaryotes by interacting with the complementary sequence in the small subunit of the ribosome.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding proteoglycans?

choices.text: Made of amino acids and sugars

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Holds less water

Holds less water: This is the correct option. Proteoglycans have a high capacity to hold water due to the presence of the highly hydrophilic glycosaminoglycan (GAG) chains. The negatively charged GAGs attract water molecules, allowing proteoglycans to maintain hydration within tissues. Therefore, the statement that proteoglycans hold less water is not true.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Carries negative charge: This is a true statement about proteoglycans. Proteoglycans are heavily glycosylated molecules composed of a core protein and long chains of repeating disaccharides called glycosaminoglycans (GAGs). The GAG chains are negatively charged due to the presence of sulfate and carboxylate groups, giving proteoglycans an overall negative charge.

Option B- Chondroitin sulfate is a good glycosaminoglycan (GAG) that is commonly found as a component of proteoglycans. Chondroitin sulfate chains can attach to a core protein to form a proteoglycan structure.

Option C - Made of amino acids and sugars: This is a true statement about proteoglycans. Proteoglycans consist of a core protein that is composed of amino acids and long chains of sugars called glycosaminoglycans (GAGs). The GAGs are made up of repeating disaccharide units, which include a sugar and an amino sugar.

questions.text: A 36 year old male with skin – colored umbilicated papules. Microscopy is as shown below. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C:

Molluscum contagiosum is the correct answer. It is a viral skin infection caused by the molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV). Molluscum contagiosum presents as skin-coloured or pearly umbilicated papules. Microscopically, it shows characteristic intracytoplasmic inclusions called molluscum bodies. These bodies consist of aggregates of viral particles surrounded by host cell reaction. The given clinical presentation of skin-coloured umbilicated papules along with the provided microscopic image of molluscum bodies strongly suggests molluscum contagiosum.

Incorrect Option:

Option A: Herpes virus. Herpes virus infections typically present with grouped vesicles or ulcers and are associated with a burning or tingling sensation. The microscopic appearance of herpes virus infection would show multinucleated giant cells and intranuclear inclusions called Cowdry bodies. This description does not match the clinical and microscopic findings provided, so herpes virus is an incorrect option.

Option B: Verruca vulgaris, also known as common warts, is caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV). Verruca vulgaris presents as rough, hyperkeratotic papules with a characteristic cauliflower-like appearance. Microscopically, verruca vulgaris would show hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, and presence of koilocytes (enlarged keratinocytes with perinuclear clearing). The given clinical presentation and microscopic image do not correspond to verruca vulgaris, so this option is incorrect.

Option D: Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by pruritic, polygonal, flat-topped papules. The microscopic findings in lichen planus include band-like lymphocytic infiltrate at the dermo-epidermal junction, known as sawtooth appearance. Lichen planus is not associated with the clinical or microscopic features described in the case, so this option is incorrect.

questions.text: In urea cycle disorders, which of the following can be used to reduce the levels of ammonia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Phenylbutyrate:

  • Phenylbutyrate is a prodrug that is metabolized in the liver to phenylacetate.
  • Phenylacetate binds with glutamine (which carries ammonia) to form phenylacetylglutamine.
  • Phenylacetylglutamine is then excreted in the urine, effectively removing ammonia from the bloodstream.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Glutamate:

  • Glutamate is an amino acid involved in various metabolic processes, including the detoxification of ammonia.
  • It can combine with ammonia to form glutamine, which helps in temporarily storing ammonia.
  • However, in urea cycle disorders, this pathway is not sufficient to handle the excess ammonia production.

Option C - Isoleucine:

  • Isoleucine is one of the essential branched-chain amino acids involved in protein synthesis and energy production.
  • It does not have a direct role in ammonia detoxification or the urea cycle.

Option D - L-carnitine:

  • L-carnitine is sometimes used in metabolic disorders to improve mitochondrial function and support energy metabolism.
  • However, it is not a primary treatment for reducing ammonia levels in urea cycle disorders.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent choices is not classified as an intermediate filament?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Tubulin:

  • Tubulin is not an intermediate filament.
  • It is a protein that polymerizes to form microtubules, which are involved in various cellular processes such as intracellular transport, cell division, and the maintenance of cell structure.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Vimentin:

  • Vimentin is an intermediate filament protein found in various types of cells, including mesenchymal cells, fibroblasts, and endothelial cells.
  • It provides structural support to the cytoskeleton and helps maintain cell shape and integrity.

Option C - Desmin:

  • Desmin is an intermediate filament protein primarily found in muscle cells, including skeletal, cardiac, and smooth muscle cells.
  • It provides structural support to muscle fibers and plays a role in maintaining muscle integrity.

Option D - Neurofilament:

  • Neurofilament is an intermediate filament protein specifically found in neurons.
  • It contributes to the structural organization of neuronal axons and provides mechanical support to the axons, allowing for efficient signal transmission.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy had painful sores in the mouth with a rash over the hands along with fever. Which of these is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Coxsackievirus: 

  • Coxsackieviruses are known to cause hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD), which presents with painful sores in the mouth, rash on the hands (and feet), and fever. Therefore, it is the most likely causative agent in this case.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pox virus: Pox viruses, typically do not cause symptoms in the mouth or rash on the hands as described in the case.

Option C - HHV-7: Human herpesvirus 7 (HHV-7) is a virus of the herpesvirus familyit is not commonly associated with sores in the mouth or a specific rash on the hands.

Option D - Parvovirus: Parvovirus B19 typically presents with a characteristic rash on the face ("slapped cheek" appearance).

questions.text: Which test evaluates the extrinsic pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - PT:

  • Prothrombin time (PT) evaluates the extrinsic pathway of coagulation.
  • It measures the time it takes for blood to clot in response to activating agents that initiate the extrinsic pathway, primarily involving factors VII, X, V, II (prothrombin), and fibrinogen.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - aPTT:

  • Activated partial thromboplastin time evaluates the intrinsic pathway of coagulation.

Option C - TT:

  • Thrombin time measures the time it takes for fibrinogen to be converted into fibrin by the action of thrombin.
  • It evaluates the final common pathway of coagulation and is used to assess the activity of thrombin.

Option D - Bleeding Time:

  • Bleeding time assesses the primary hemostasis, specifically the ability of platelets to form a platelet plug and initiate clot formation.
  • It measures the time it takes for bleeding to stop after a standardized skin incision.

questions.text: A patient with fever and joint pain developed pigmentation on the nose after a few days of taking NSAIDs as shown below. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D. Chikungunya: Chikungunya is a viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes. It is characterized by symptoms such as high fever, joint pain, muscle pain, headache, and rash. The development of pigmentation on the nose after taking NSAIDs is not a typical feature of chikungunya. Other symptoms, such as joint pain and fever, are more indicative of this diagnosis.

 

Incorrect option:

Option A. Melasma: Melasma is a common skin condition characterized by brown or gray patches on the face, particularly on the cheeks, forehead, and upper lip. It is not associated with fever or joint pain, so it is not the correct diagnosis in this case.

Option B. Fixed drug eruption: Fixed drug eruption is a type of drug-induced skin reaction characterized by the development of well-defined, round or oval-shaped patches that recur in the same location each time the drug is taken. It typically presents as red or purplish lesions, but pigmentation on the nose is not a typical feature of fixed drug eruption.

OptionC. Lichen planus: Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory condition that can affect the skin, mucous membranes, hair, and nails. It presents as itchy, flat-topped, purplish bumps that may have white streaks or lines on them. Pigmentation on the nose is not a characteristic feature of lichen planus.

questions.text: What type of calcification is likely to be seen in a 58-year-old man who died 24 hours after experiencing substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm, with an autopsy revealing an obstructing atheromatous plaque in the left anterior descending artery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Dystrophic with normal serum calcium:

  • The type of calcification seen in atheroma is dystrophic calcification.
  • Metastatic calcification:
    • Metastatic calcification is caused by increased calcium phosphate in the blood and may result from hypercalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, or both.
    • It is commonly associated with hyperparathyroidism, sarcoidosis, metastatic disease, and myeloma.
  • Dystrophic calcification:
    • The deposition of calcium salt in degenerated tissues in the absence of a systemic imbalance is called dystrophic calcification.
    • It is mostly associated with trauma, inflammation, or infection.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: Topical steroids are most effective in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Eczematous dermatitis:

  • Topical steroids are most effective in the treatment of eczematous dermatitis.
  • Eczematous dermatitis refers to a group of inflammatory skin conditions characterized by redness, itching, and scaling. These conditions include atopic dermatitis, contact dermatitis, and seborrheic dermatitis.
  • Topical steroids have potent anti-inflammatory properties and are commonly used to reduce inflammation, itching, and redness associated with eczematous dermatitis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dermal atrophy: Topical steroids, can cause dermal atrophy, thinning of the skin, and loss of elasticity. This adverse effect is not the desired outcome of treatment.

Option C - Bullous lesion due to HSV: Topical steroids are generally not recommended for the treatment of bullous lesions caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection.s.

Option D - Rosacea: While topical steroids may provide temporary relief for some symptoms of rosacea, they are not considered the primary treatment for this condition.

questions.text: A patient was treated with steroids for psoriasis. On stopping the treatment, he develops fever, malaise, and lesion as seen in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pustular psoriasis:

  • Pustular psoriasis is a form of psoriasis characterized by the presence of widespread, sterile pustules on the skin.
  • It can be triggered by the withdrawal of systemic steroids. The fever, malaise, and pustular lesions seen in the image are consistent with this diagnosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Staphylococcal infection: Staphylococcal infections can cause localized or widespread pustules on the skin. However,it does not have the history of steroid treatment

Option C - Acute generalized exanthematous pustulosis (AGEP): AGEP is a rare, severe cutaneous reaction characterized by the rapid onset of numerous sterile pustulesHowever, the clinical presentation and history of steroid use in this case are more consistent with pustular psoriasis.

Option D - Subcorneal pustulosis: Subcorneal pustulosist typically presents with localized lesions, and the widespread involvement seen in the image is not characteristic of subcorneal pustulosis.

questions.text: A patient presents with a flaccid bullous lesion involving the oral cavity and the skin. He has lesions as shown below. Acantholytic cells are seen on Tzanck smear. What is the most probable diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Pemphigus vulgaris:

  • Pemphigus vulgaris: Pemphigus vulgaris commonly presents with flaccid bullae involving both the oral cavity and the skin. The presence of acantholytic cells on Tzanck smear further supports the diagnosis. Thus, Pemphigus vulgaris is the most probable diagnosis in this case.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pemphigus foliaceus: Pemphigus foliaceus is a superficial variant of pemphigus, characterized by flaccid bullae on the skin. However, it typically spares the oral cavity.

Option C - Dermatitis herpetiformis: It typically presents with intensely itchy papules and vesicles, rather than large flaccid bullae seen in the provided image.

Option D - Bullous pemphigoid: Acantholytic cells are not typically seen in bullous pemphigoid. Therefore, this diagnosis is less likely in the given case.

questions.text: Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to the plasma by binding to:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Ferroportin:

  • Ferroportin is a transmembrane protein found on the surface of enterocytes and macrophages.
  • It is responsible for exporting iron from these cells into the bloodstream.
  • Hepcidin, a peptide hormone produced by the liver, binds to ferroportin and triggers its internalization and degradation.
  • This inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to the plasma, reducing iron absorption.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Transferrin: Transferrin is a plasma protein that binds to iron and transports it in the bloodstream.

Option C - Divalent metal transporter-1 (DMT-1): Divalent metal transporter-1 (DMT-1) is a transmembrane protein involved in the uptake of various divalent metals, including iron, into the enterocyte.

Option D - Ferritin: Ferritin is an intracellular protein that serves as the primary storage form of iron in cells.

questions.text: A 16 year old girl, who is taking antiepileptics, has had a seizure-free period of 6 months. She has no family history of epilepsy. Her EEG is now normal and she has a normal neurological exam and intelligence. What would be your advice?

choices.text: Stop the treatment and follow up
Gradually taper the drug and stop treatment

questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option c: Continue treatment for another 2 years: This option is correct. The recommended approach in this scenario is to continue treatment for another 2 years. The duration of seizure freedom required before considering discontinuation of antiepileptic drugs varies, but typically 2-5 years of seizure freedom is considered an appropriate period.

 

Incorrect Option:

Option a. Stop the treatment and follow up: This option is incorrect. The 16-year-old girl has been seizure-free for 6 months, but it does not necessarily mean that she can safely stop the treatment altogether. Stopping the treatment abruptly can increase the risk of seizure recurrence.

Option b. Gradually taper the drug and stop treatment: This option is incorrect. While the girl has been seizure-free for 6 months, it is generally recommended to continue treatment for a longer period before considering tapering and stopping the antiepileptic drug. Gradual tapering of the drug under medical supervision may be considered later, but not at this stage.

Optiond. Continue lifelong treatment with antiepileptics: This option is incorrect. Lifelong treatment with antiepileptic drugs is not necessary in all cases. If the girl remains seizure-free for a prolonged period (usually 2-5 years), there may be an opportunity to gradually taper and discontinue the medication under medical supervision.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding polycythemia vera?

choices.text: Risk of thrombosis strongly correlates with the degree of thrombocytosis
Generalized pruritus is a consequence of mast cell activation by JAK 2 mutation
It is protective against H. Pylori infection
Acute myeloid leukaemia is the most common cause of mortality

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Generalized pruritus is a consequence of mast cell activation by JAK2 mutation:

  • In polycythemia vera, a mutation in the JAK2 gene (JAK2 V617F mutation) is commonly observed. This mutation leads to the overactivation of certain cells, including mast cells, which release mediators that can cause generalized pruritus (itching) as a characteristic symptom of the disease.

Other clinical features include high haemoglobin, or with symptoms of hyperviscosity, such as lassitude, loss of concentration, headaches, dizziness, blackouts, pruritus and epistaxis

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Risk of thrombosis strongly correlates with the degree of thrombocytosis: While polycythemia vera is associated with an increased risk of thrombosis, the degree of thrombocytosis alone does not strongly correlate with the risk.sk.

Option C - It is protective against H. pylori infection: Polycythemia vera does not confer protection against Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) infection.

Option D - Acute myeloid leukemia is the most common cause of mortality: While patients with polycythemia vera have an increased risk of developing acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and other myeloproliferative neoplasms, it is not the most common cause of mortality in polycythemia vera.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male admitted to the ICU for acute exacerbation of COPD develops a sudden onset of palpitations. The following ECG changes are seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B: Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is characterized by an irregular rhythm with at least three distinct P-wave morphologies in the same lead. The ECG changes described in the scenario, specifically the presence of multiple P-wave morphologies, are consistent with MAT.

 

Incorrect Option:

Option A: Ventricular tachycardia (VT) is characterized by wide QRS complexes and is usually a regular rhythm. The ECG shown in the scenario does not exhibit the characteristics of VT.

Option C: Atrial fibrillation (AF) is characterized by irregularly irregular rhythm with absent P waves and irregularly spaced QRS complexes. The scenario does not describe the absence of P waves, making AF less likely.

Option D: Atrial tachycardia is characterized by a regular rhythm with a single P-wave morphology. The presence of multiple P-wave morphologies in the ECG suggests a different diagnosis than atrial tachycardia.

questions.text: A CKD patient had to undergo dialysis, and his Hb was 5.2 g/dL. So two blood transfusions were to be given. The first bag was completed in 2 hours. The second was started, and in the midway, he developed shortness of breath and hypertension. Vitals were BP: 180/120 mmHg and pulse rate: 110/min. What is the cause?
questions.solution:
Correct option B: Transfusion-related circulatory overload:

  • Transfusion-related circulatory overload (TACO) occurs when a patient receives blood or fluid too quickly.
  • In the given case, the patient undergoing dialysis received two blood transfusions. overwhelming the cardiovascular system's capacity to handle the increased volume.
  • Symptoms of TACO include shortness of breath, hypertension, elevated blood pressure, and fluid overload.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Allergic reaction: While allergic reactions can occur during transfusions, they typically present with symptoms such as itching, rash, hives, or anaphylaxis.

Option C: Transfusion-related acute lung injury:

  • TRALI is a rare but potentially serious complication of blood transfusion characterized by acute respiratory distress and pulmonary edema.
  • While shortness of breath is a symptom of TRALI, hypertension and elevated blood pressure are not typically associated with this condition.

Option D: Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction: A febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction is characterized by fever and chills during or after a blood transfusion, usually due to antibodies in the recipient's blood reacting to donor leukocytes.

questions.text: Deep y descent in JVP is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A: Cardiac tamponade typically presents with an elevated JVP but a blunted or absent y descent due to impaired filling of the right ventricle during diastole. Therefore, deep y descent is not seen in cardiac tamponade.

 

Incorrect Option:

Option B: Restrictive cardiomyopathy is characterized by stiffening of the heart muscle, leading to impaired ventricular filling. It can result in a prominent and rapid y descent in the JVP waveform.

Option C: Constrictive pericarditis involves the thickening and stiffening of the pericardium, leading to impaired cardiac filling. It is associated with a prominent and rapid y descent in the JVP waveform.

Option D: Tricuspid regurgitation is a condition in which the tricuspid valve fails to close properly, causing blood to flow backward into the right atrium during systole. This leads to an elevated JVP and a large v wave. Steep y descent is seen

questions.text: Tigroid white matter on MR imaging is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option

Option B: Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease is a genetic disorder characterized by abnormal myelination of the central nervous system. The tigroid white matter appearance on MR imaging is a classic finding in this condition due to alternating areas of myelination and demyelination

 

Incorrect Option:

Option A: Pantothenate kinase deficiency is a rare neurodegenerative disorder characterized by impaired synthesis of coenzyme A (CoA). It is not specifically associated with a tigroid white matter pattern on MR imaging.

Option C: Neuroferritinopathy is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder characterized by abnormal iron deposition in the brain. It typically does not present with a tigroid white matter pattern on MR imaging.

Option D: Aceruloplasminemia is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the absence or dysfunction of ceruloplasmin, leading to abnormal iron metabolism. It is not specifically associated with a tigroid white matter pattern on MR imaging.

questions.text: What is the most common pulmonary manifestation of SLE?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Pleuritis:

  • Pleuritis, inflammation of the pleura (the membranes lining the lungs and chest cavity), is the most common pulmonary manifestation of SLE. It can cause chest pain, pleural effusion (accumulation of fluid in the pleural space), and a characteristic friction rub on auscultation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Shrinking lung syndrome: Shrinking lung syndrome is a rare complication of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) characterized by progressive dyspnea and restrictive lung function. However, it is not the most common pulmonary manifestation of SLE.

Option C - Intra-alveolar hemorrhage: Intra-alveolar hemorrhage refers to bleeding into the air sacs of the lungs. While it can occur in SLE, it is less common compared to pleuritis.

Option D - Interstitial inflammation: Interstitial inflammation refers to inflammation of the lung interstitium, which is the tissue between the air sacs. While interstitial lung disease can occur in SLE, it is not the most common pulmonary manifestation.

questions.text: A patient who receives recurrent transfusions for thalassemia develops fever and chills during this time. There is no evidence of hemolysis. Which of the following measures can decrease the rate of transfusion reactions?
questions.solution:
Correct option A: Leukoreduced RBCs:

  • The patient's presentation with fever and chills with no evidence of hemolysis is suggestive of a febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction.
  • Leukoreduced red blood cells (RBCs) refer to blood products that have undergone a process to remove or reduce the number of leukocytes.
  • White blood cells can trigger immune responses and cause transfusion reactions, including febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions.
  • Leukoreduced RBCs reduce the risk of febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions.

Incorrect options: Options B, C, and D do not reduce the risk of febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions.

questions.text: True about the definition of postural hypotension:

choices.text: Decrease in systolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 6 mins of standing
Decrease in systolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 3 min of standing
Decrease in diastolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 6 mins of standing
Decrease in diastolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 3 mins of standing

questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option B: Decrease in systolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 3 min of standing: This option is correct. Postural hypotension, also known as orthostatic hypotension, is defined as a decrease in systolic blood pressure of 20 mmHg or more or a decrease in diastolic blood pressure of 10 mmHg or more within 3 minutes of standing up from a sitting or lying position

 

Incorrect Option:

Option A: Decrease in systolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 6 mins of standing: This option is incorrect. The definition of postural hypotension does not specify a specific duration of standing as 6 minutes.

Option C: Decrease in diastolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 6 mins of standing: This option is incorrect. The definition of postural hypotension does not specify a specific duration of standing as 6 minutes, and it focuses on the systolic blood pressure drop rather than the diastolic blood pressure drop.

Option D: Decrease in diastolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 3 mins of standing: This option is incorrect. While a decrease in diastolic blood pressure can contribute to postural hypotension, the primary criterion for its diagnosis is a decrease in systolic blood pressure of 20 mmHg or more.

questions.text: If DNA is damaged in the cell cycle, which gene causes cell cycle arrest?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - p53:

  • p53 is a tumor suppressor gene that is often referred to as the guardian of the genome.
  • It plays a crucial role in monitoring DNA integrity and orchestrating cellular responses to DNA damage.
  • When DNA is damaged, p53 is activated and can induce cell cycle arrest, allowing time for DNA repair or triggering apoptosis if the damage is irreparable.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - RB: The RB gene is involved in regulating the cell cycle by inhibiting the progression from the G1 phase to the S phase.

Option B - Myc: The Myc is an oncogene that plays a role in cell growth and proliferation.

Option D - KRAS: The KRAS gene is an oncogene involved in cell signalling pathways that regulate cell growth and proliferation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a haemostatic agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C.

Boric acid: Boric acid is not commonly used as a hemostatic agent. It is primarily used in various industrial and pharmaceutical applications, but it does not have specific hemostatic properties.

Incorrect Option

Option A: Zeolite: Zeolite is a mineral-based compound that has been used as a hemostatic agent. It works by absorbing water and promoting clot formation at the site of bleeding.

Option B. Chitosan: Chitosan is a biopolymer derived from chitin, which is found in the exoskeleton of crustaceans. Chitosan-based products have been used as hemostatic agents due to their ability to promote clotting and accelerate wound healing.

Option D. Kaolin: Kaolin is a naturally occurring clay mineral that has hemostatic properties. It acts by activating the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade and promoting clot formation.

questions.text:
Calculate the anion gap from the following values:

Na+ = 137 mmol/L

K+ = 4 mmol/L

CI- = 100 mmol/L

HCO3- = 15 mmol/L
questions.solution:
Correct Option:  A) 22 mmol/L

 

The anion gap is a calculated value used to evaluate the cause of a metabolic acidosis. It represents the difference between the measured cations and measured anions in the blood.

The standard formula for calculating the anion gap is:

Anion Gap = [Na⁺] - ([Cl⁻] + [HCO₃⁻])

Given the values: [Na+] = 137 mmol/L

[Cl-] = 100 mmol/L

[HCO3-] = 15 mmol/L

Anion Gap = 137 - (100 + 15) = 137 - 115 = 22 mmol/L

questions.text: An affected male does not have affected children, but an affected female always has affected children. What is the type of inheritance?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Mitochondrial:

  • Mitochondrial inheritance involves the transmission of genetic material exclusively through the maternal line via mitochondria.
  • Mitochondrial DNA is inherited from the mother, and therefore, affected females always pass the mitochondrial gene to all of their children, resulting in all of their children being affected.
  • Affected males do not pass the mitochondrial gene to their children, and they do not have affected children.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man was brought to the OPD with complaints of multiple hyperpigmented skin macules which started in his childhood. These fibromas near the eyelid have increased in size causing visual disturbance. Identify the disease shown in the below image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Plexiform neurofibromatosis:

Plexiform neurofibromatosis is a subtype of neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), a genetic disorder characterized by the development of neurofibromas, which are benign tumors arising from nerve tissue. Plexiform neurofibromas involve multiple nerves and can cause disfigurement and functional impairments.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Facial nerve palsy: Facial nerve palsy refers to the weakness or paralysis of the muscles innervated by the facial nerve.

Option C - Masticator space abscess: Masticator space abscess refers to an abscess (collection of pus) within the masticator space, which is an anatomical region containing the muscles of mastication (chewing).

Option D - Fibrous dysplasia: Fibrous dysplasia is a bone disorder characterized by the abnormal development of fibrous tissue within the bone, leading to weakening and deformity.

questions.text: Which of the following is a sign of irreversible cell injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Amorphous densities in mitochondria:

  • Mitochondrial changes, such as swelling and dysfunction, are associated with irreversible cell injury.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are associated with reversible cell injury.

questions.text: A patient of haemophilia received multiple blood transfusions. Which of the following metabolic abnormalities can be seen in a patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Metabolic alkalosis:

  • In patients with haemophilia who receive multiple blood transfusions, metabolic alkalosis can occur as a result of the citrate anticoagulant used in stored blood products.
  • Citrate toxicity causes raised pH leading to redistribution of potassium eventually causing metabolic alkalosis.

 

Incorrect Option:

Option B - Respiratory alkalosis: Respiratory alkalosis is characterized by a decrease in arterial carbon dioxide (CO2) levels, resulting in an increase in blood pH.

Option C - Metabolic acidosis: Metabolic acidosis is characterized by a decrease in blood pH and bicarbonate levels.

Option D - Respiratory acidosis: Respiratory acidosis is characterized by an increase in arterial carbon dioxide (CO2) levels, resulting in a decrease in blood pH.

questions.text: Which of the following is the major source of plasma Von Willebrand factor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Endothelial Cells:

  • Endothelial cells, which line the blood vessels, are the primary source of plasma von Willebrand factor.
  • These cells synthesize and release vWF into the bloodstream.
  • Von Willebrand factor produced by endothelial cells plays a crucial role in blood clotting and platelet adhesion to damaged blood vessel walls.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are incorrect.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presented with a gradually diminishing visual field. She was found to have a pituitary mass and underwent trans-sphenoidal hypophysectomy. Now she has low levels of ACTH, TSH, FSH and LH. Which of the following hormone supplements is not needed in the patient postoperatively?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Mineralocorticoids:

  • Mineralocorticoids, such as aldosterone, are responsible for regulating electrolyte and water balance in the body. They are not produced by the pituitary gland but rather by the adrenal cortex.
  • Therefore, the patient's deficiency in ACTH (adrenocorticotropic hormone) will not directly affect mineralocorticoid production. Hence, mineralocorticoid supplementation is not needed in this case.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Thyroid hormones: Thyroid hormones, including TSH (thyroid-stimulating hormone), play a crucial role in regulating metabolism. As the patient has low levels of TSH, indicating thyroid hormone deficiency, thyroid hormone supplementation is necessary to maintain normal thyroid function.

Option C - Glucocorticoids: Glucocorticoids, such as cortisol, are produced by the adrenal cortex under the stimulation of ACTH. With the deficiency of ACTH, the production of glucocorticoids is reduced. Therefore, glucocorticoid supplementation is needed to replace the deficient cortisol and provide the necessary physiological effects.

Option D - Estradiol: Estradiol is a female sex hormone produced primarily by the ovaries. The deficiency of FSH (follicle-stimulating hormone) and LH (luteinizing hormone) indicates dysfunction of the gonadotropins, which regulate the production of estradiol. Consequently, estradiol supplementation may be required to maintain hormonal balance in premenopausal women.

questions.text: Both intrinsic and extrinsic pathways are seen in :
questions.solution:
Correct Option A.

Apoptosis: This option is correct. Apoptosis is a programmed cell death process characterized by controlled and regulated cell dismantling. It can be initiated through both intrinsic and extrinsic pathways. The intrinsic pathway is triggered by internal signals, such as DNA damage or cellular stress, leading to the release of cytochrome c from the mitochondria. The extrinsic pathway is initiated by external signals, such as binding of death ligands (e.g., Fas ligand) to death receptors on the cell surface.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Necrosis: This option is incorrect. Necrosis is a form of cell death that occurs due to uncontrolled injury or damage. It is characterized by cell swelling, membrane rupture, and the release of cellular contents into the surrounding tissue. Necrosis does not involve the intrinsic or extrinsic pathways seen in apoptosis, as it is not a programmed process.

Option C: Necroptosis: This option is incorrect. Necroptosis is a programmed form of necrosis, distinct from apoptosis, that occurs under specific conditions. It is triggered by certain death receptors, such as tumor necrosis factor receptor 1 (TNFR1) and involves a cascade of intracellular events leading to cell death. However, necroptosis does not involve the intrinsic or extrinsic pathways associated with apoptosis.

Option D: Pyroptosis: This option is incorrect. Pyroptosis is a highly inflammatory form of programmed cell death that occurs in response to infection or cellular stress. It is characterized by the formation of large pores in the plasma membrane, leading to cell lysis and the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines. Pyroptosis is distinct from apoptosis and does not involve the intrinsic or extrinsic pathways seen in apoptosis.

questions.text: The ECG of a pregnant lady having pre-eclampsia is shown below. Her vitals are stable. What is the best step in the management of the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option b. IV MgSO4 (Magnesium sulfate): Magnesium sulfate is the preferred treatment for torsades des pointes, especially in the setting of pre-eclampsia. Magnesium sulfate has antiarrhythmic properties and can effectively stabilize the cardiac rhythm.

 

Incorrect Option:

Option a. IV calcium: Intravenous calcium is not the recommended treatment for torsades des pointes. It is more commonly used in the management of calcium channel blocker overdose or hypocalcemia.

Option c. DC shock: Direct current (DC) shock, also known as defibrillation, is not the primary treatment for torsades des pointes. It is typically reserved for life-threatening ventricular arrhythmias such as ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia.

Option d. Synchronized cardioversion: Synchronized cardioversion is not the appropriate treatment for torsades des pointes. It is used for the conversion of certain supraventricular tachycardias and hemodynamically unstable ventricular arrhythmias.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given serum electrophoresis image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Nephrotic Syndrome:

  • Nephrotic syndrome is a kidney disorder characterized by the abnormal leakage of proteins, particularly albumin, into the urine.
  • This results in hypoalbuminemia.
  • On serum electrophoresis, nephrotic syndrome can present with a characteristic pattern of decreased albumin levels and a prominent alpha-2 band.
  • The decreased albumin leads to a decrease in the albumin peak, and the alpha-2 band becomes more prominent relative to the albumin peak.

Incorrect Options: 

  • Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: A skin biopsy sample was taken and sent for histopathological examination. The characteristic microscopic body, as shown in the image, was seen. Which of the following could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Chromoblastomycosis:

  • This is a micrograph of chromoblastomycosis caused by Phialophora verrucosa and Fonsecaea pedrosoi, showing the sclerotic bodies, aka copper penny bodies, or muriform bodies.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a small round blue cell tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hemangioblastoma:

  • Hemangioblastoma is not a small round blue cell tumor.
  • It is a rare, benign tumor that arises from the blood vessels in the central nervous system.
  • Histologically, it is characterized by abundant blood vessels and stromal cells.
  • It is commonly associated with von Hippel-Lindau disease, an inherited condition that predisposes individuals to the development of various tumors.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ewing's sarcoma:

  • Ewing's sarcoma is a malignant tumor that predominantly affects children and young adults.
  • It is characterized by small round blue cells with a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio.
  • It commonly arises in the bones, but it can also occur in soft tissues.
  • Ewing's sarcoma often presents with localized pain and swelling and can metastasize to other sites.

Option C - Retinoblastoma:

  • Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor that develops in the retina of the eye.
  • It primarily affects children and can occur unilaterally or bilaterally.
  • Retinoblastoma is characterized by small round blue cells and can cause leukocoria and visual disturbances.
  • It is associated with mutations in the RB1 gene.

Option D - Neuroblastoma:

  • Neuroblastoma is a malignant tumor that arises from primitive nerve cells, typically in the adrenal glands or along the sympathetic nervous system.
  • It is the most common extracranial solid tumor in children.
  • Neuroblastoma is composed of small round blue cells and can present with various signs and symptoms, including abdominal mass, bone pain, and neurologic changes.

questions.text: An HIV patient with fever and chronic diarrhea presented to OPD. His stool was examined, and it showed the following oocysts. Identify the components used for staining the stool.

choices.text: Crystal violet, iodine, acid alcohol, kinyoun carbol fuchsin
Kinyoun carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, methylene blue
Methanol, dilute carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, crystal violet
Methylene blue, iodine, acid alcohol, kinyoun carbol fuchsin

questions.solution:
Correct Option B -  Kinyoun carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, methylene blue:

  • The presentation of diarrhea in an immunocompromised individual and the image showing an acid-fast oocyst suggestive of infection by coccidian parasites like cryptosporidium, cyclospora, and isosopora.
  • The stain used is a modification of the Ziehl Neelsen staining, in which heat is not used as a mordant, instead an increased concentration of phenol in the primary stain, i.e., carbol fuschin is used as a mordant, hence known as Cold Ziehl Neelsen staining or Gabbet's stain or Kinyoun staining 
  • Procedure of Kinyoun staining:
    • Kinyoun's carbol fuchsin: This is a modified acid-fast stain that is used to stain the Cryptosporidium oocysts. It helps visualize the oocysts under the microscope.
    • Acid alcohol: Acid alcohol (5% H2SO4 and 95% ethanol) is used as a decolorizing agent to remove excess stain from the sample.
    • Methylene blue: Methylene blue is a counterstain that is applied after the decolorization step. It helps in enhancing the contrast and visualization of the stained oocysts.

Incorrect Option:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with Hepatitis B infection. Which of the following markers will always be present in his serum, even during recurrences, or if he develops chronic hepatitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Anti HBc Ab:

  • Anti-HBcAb (Antibodies against Hepatitis B core antigen) is present during and after the acute phase of Hepatitis B infection. It persists in the serum even during recurrences and in individuals with chronic hepatitis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - HBc Ag: Hepatitis B core antigen is not detectable in the serum.

Option B - Anti HBs Ab: Antibodies against Hepatitis B surface antigen indicates immunity to Hepatitis B following vaccination.

Option D - HBe Ag: Hepatitis B pre-core antigen typically suggests the infectivity of the virus; presence of this antigen suggests high infectivity, and the absence suggests low infectivity.

questions.text: Transmission assessment survey is carried out for?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Filariasis:

  • The Transmission Assessment Survey (TAS) is carried out for filariasis, which is caused by parasitic worms transmitted through mosquito bites. The TAS helps assess the transmission of filariasis, monitor the progress of elimination programs, and determine if interventions have successfully reduced the prevalence of the disease in endemic areas or if mass drug administration is required or not.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Transmission assessment survey is one for Filariasis.

questions.text: A patient presents with Renal calculus of  > 4 cm of the staghorn type. What is the best management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy and ESWL:

  • Staghorn Calculi Size: The patient presents with a staghorn calculus of over 4 cm in size. PCNL  and ESWL (Sandwich technique) is used in the preferred management for such large stones.

  • Indications for PCNL:

    • Stone size larger than 2 cm: The staghorn calculus clearly exceeds this size threshold.

    • Presence of distal obstruction: Staghorn calculi can cause obstruction in the urinary tract.

    • Urinary Tract Infection (UTI): Staghorn calculi are often associated with UTIs.

    • Stone hardness, especially hard stones like BHC-2: Staghorn calculi tend to be hard.

    • Stones located in the lower calyx: PCNL is particularly effective for stones in this location.

  • Combined Approach for Staghorn Calculi:

    • For staghorn calculi, a combined approach of PCNL and ESWL (Sandwich technique) is used. This combines the advantages of both methods for better stone fragmentation and clearance.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - ESWL:

  • While (Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy) ESWL is effective for smaller stones, it's less suitable for large staghorn calculi like the one presented here (>4 cm).

  • Staghorn calculi often require multiple sessions of ESWL, which may not be as effective as PCNL for complete clearance.

Option C - Ureteroscopic Removal:

  • Ureteroscopic removal is not ideal for staghorn calculi due to their large size and complex shape.

  • Ureteroscopy is more suitable for smaller stones located in the ureter or smaller renal calculi.

Option D - Retro Renal Surgery:

  • Retro renal surgery is not a standard treatment for renal calculi, especially with the availability of less invasive techniques like PCNL.

  • It may be considered in rare and complex cases where other methods are not feasible, but it's not the primary choice for staghorn calculi.

questions.text: A hospital has reported an outbreak of MRSA infection. On investigation, it was found out that a staff nurse had nasal carriage of MRSA. Which of the following drugs helps in the removal of colonization of bacteria?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Topical mupirocin:

MRSA Spread

  • The most common form of spread is via the hands of healthcare workers.

Precaution

  • Perform rigorous hand washing.
  • Elimination involves:
    • Administration of ointment mupirocin for nasal carriers
    • Chlorhexidine washes for other sites of the body.

Treatment of MRSA

  • Vancomycin
  • Daptomycin.

Incorrect Option:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to option C for an explanation.

questions.text: What is the best position for a conscious patient to be in during the insertion of a Ryle's tube?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Sitting with neck flexion:

  • Sitting position allows the patient's head to be slightly flexed forward, which helps to align the nasal passage for easier insertion of the tube. The flexed position helps straighten the path from the nostril to the throat, facilitating the passage of the tube through the nasal passage and into the stomach.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Supine with neck flexion: Neck flexion may cause difficulty in visualizing and accessing the patient's nasal passage, making the procedure more challenging.

Option B - Supine with neck extension: Neck extension can obstruct the airway and may cause discomfort or difficulty in passing the tube through the nasal passage.

Option D - Sitting with neck extension: Neck extension can obstruct the airway and may cause discomfort to the patient. It can also make it more challenging to insert the tube properl

questions.text: Which toxin acts via the mechanism depicted in the image below ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Botulinum:

  • Botulinum toxin is produced by the bacterium Clostridium botulinum and has a specific mechanism of action
  • Mechanism of action:
    • Binding: Botulinum toxin binds to presynaptic nerve terminals at the neuromuscular junction.
    • Internalization: The toxin is internalized into the nerve terminal via receptor-mediated endocytosis.
    • Cleavage: Inside the nerve terminal, the toxin undergoes enzymatic cleavage, resulting in the formation of two subunits: a light chain (LC) and a heavy chain (HC).
    • Neurotransmitter release inhibition: The light chain (LC) of the botulinum toxin is a protease that specifically cleaves SNARE proteins involved in neurotransmitter release. SNARE proteins play a crucial role in the fusion of synaptic vesicles containing acetylcholine with the neuronal membrane, allowing the release of acetylcholine into the synaptic cleft. By cleaving SNARE proteins, botulinum toxin prevents the release of acetylcholine, leading to muscle paralysis.
    • Temporary effects: The effects of botulinum toxin are reversible, as new SNARE proteins can be synthesized by the affected neuron over time. The duration of paralysis depends on the type of botulinum toxin used and the individual's metabolism.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with a history of urethral discharge for the last three days. A gram stain smear of the discharge is shown below. All of the following are true regarding the likely etiology except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Ferments Maltose:

  • The clinical presentation of urethral discharge is suggestive of urethritis, and the presence of gram-negative intracellular diplococci in the microscopic image suggests the likely causative organism is Neisseria gonorrhea.
