questions.text: Which of the following colored cannula will you use to achieve maximum flow rate, in a patient who needs a large amount of fluids?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Grey:

  • Grey cannulas typically have the largest diameter (16G) among the options listed, allowing for a higher flow rate of fluids.

Incorrect Option:

Option B - Green cannula: Green cannulas are smaller in diameter (18G) compared to the Grey cannula.

Option C - Blue cannula: Blue cannulas are smaller in diameter (22G) than both Grey and Green cannulas.

Option D - Pink cannula: Pink cannulas are the smallest in diameter (20G) among the options listed. They are commonly used for patients who require a low flow rate, such as for pediatric patients or those with fragile veins.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes multiple alveolar-like lesions in the liver?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Echinococcus Multilocularis:

  • Echinococcus multilocularis is a parasitic tapeworm that causes alveolar echinococcosis. It can form multiple cyst and inside single cyst multiple locules are present leading to multiple alveolar-like lesions in the liver, hence called alveolar hydatid cyst/multilocularis. The lesions are invasive and can infiltrate surrounding tissues.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Echinococcus Granulosus: Echinococcus granulosus is another parasitic tapeworm that causes hydatid cysts. Multiple cysts are present, filled with fluid, which may cause anaphylaxis if drained in the body.

Option C - Entamoeba Histolytica: Entamoeba histolytica is a protozoan parasite that causes amoebic dysentery and liver abscesses. It affects the right lobe of the liver and presents with an abscess described as anchovy sauce.

Option D - Cysticercus Cellulosae: Cysticercus cellulosae is the larval stage of the pork tapeworm Taenia solium responsible for causing cysticercosis, characterized by multiple calcified cysts an multiple organs.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the casualty after an RTA. He has chest trauma, respiratory rate of 44 and BP is 90/40 mm/Hg. He is conscious and speaks single words. There is a hyper-resonance on the involved side of his chest. What will be your next, immediate step?

choices.text: Insert needle in appropriate intercostal space

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Insert needle in appropriate intercostal space:

  • The presence of hyper-resonance on the involved side of the chest, along with the patient's clinical findings (chest trauma, respiratory distress, hypotension), suggests a potential tension pneumothorax.
  • Inserting a needle in the appropriate intercostal space (needle thoracostomy) is an emergency procedure used to decompress the accumulated air in the chest and relieve the tension. This intervention takes precedence in this situation.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Intubate: Intubation may be necessary in certain cases, particularly if the patient's airway is compromised or if there are signs of respiratory distress. However, in this specific scenario, the patient's respiratory rate of 44 suggests that he is still maintaining his airway and breathing adequately. Therefore, intubation is not the immediate priority.

Option C - Start intravenous fluids urgently: While administering intravenous fluids may be necessary for the management of hypotension, in this case, the primary concern is the potential tension pneumothorax.

Option D - Take a chest X-ray: Chest X-ray is an important diagnostic tool to confirm the presence of a pneumothorax and assess its severity. However, in this critical scenario with signs of tension pneumothorax, waiting for a chest X-ray could cause significant delay in appropriate management. I

questions.text: A Giemsa stain of a thin peripheral smear is prepared. Which of the following cannot be diagnosed ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Coxiella Burnetii:

  • Coxiella burnetii is the causative agent of Q fever, and its diagnosis is typically done through serological testing or PCR. Giemsa stain of a thin peripheral smear is not effective in visualizing this organism.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Trypanosoma Parasites: Giemsa stain can be used to detect Trypanosoma parasites in peripheral blood smears. It allows for the visualization of it.

Option C - Whirling Disease: Giemsa stain can be used to identify Whirling disease. 

Option D - Karyotyping: Giemsa stain can be used in Karyotyping

questions.text: What is the most frequently encountered tumor in the mediastinum?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Neurogenic tumors:

  • Most common posterior mediastinal mass  and also overall  most common mediastinal mass are neurogenic tumors

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Thymoma: Thymoma is a tumor that originates from the thymus gland, which is located in the mediastinum. They are the most common anterior mediastinal mass

Option C - Lymphoma: Lymphomas are cancers that originate from lymphocytes, a type of white blood cell. While lymphomas can involve the mediastinum, they are not as common as thymomas.

Option D - Bronchial cyst: Bronchial cysts are abnormal fluid-filled sacs that develop within the bronchial walls. While they can occur in the mediastinum, they are not the most common mediastinal tumors.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions cannot be diagnosed using the β 1-3 glucan assay?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Mucormycosis:

  • β-1,3-D Glucan is a polysaccharide cell wall component of fungi.
    • Beta 1,3 D glucan assay is commonly used for diagnosis of Candida and Aspergillus.
    • Other organisms showing positive β-1,3-D Glucan assay are Pneumocystis jirrovecii pneumonia, Histoplasma, Fusarium, Scedosparium, and dermatophytes.
    • Organisms with negative β-1,3-D Glucan assay are Cryptococcus, mucorales (rhizopus and mucor), and Blastomyces dermatitidis.
  • Mucorales are responsible for causing mucormycosis and cannot be diagnosed by using β-1,3-D Glucan assay.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to Option D for an explanation.

questions.text: The probable diagnosis based on the below clinical image of the breast is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Mondor's disease:

  • Mondor's disease, also known as Mondor's phlebitis, is a rare condition characterized by inflammation and thrombosis of the superficial veins of the breast or chest wall involving the lateral thoracic vein.
  • It presents with a palpable cord-like structure under the skin, often accompanied by pain and redness. It typically resolves spontaneously within a few weeks.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Paget's disease: Paget's disease of the breast is a rare form of breast cancer that affects the skin and nipple. It typically presents with symptoms such as itching, redness, flaking, and crusting of the nipple and surrounding areola. It is less likely to be the probable diagnosis based solely on the information that a clinical image of the breast is provided.

Option C - Zuska's disease: Zuska's disease is not a recognized medical condition related to breast disorders. Therefore, it is an incorrect option.

Option D - Tietze syndrome: Tietze syndrome is a rare inflammatory condition characterized by swelling and tenderness of the cartilage that connects the ribs to the breastbone (sternum). It typically causes localized chest pain and swelling. While it involves the chest area, it is not directly related to breast disorders, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient came to the emergency with pain in the epigastrium radiating to the back and recurrent vomiting. On examination, guarding was present in the upper epigastrium. The erect chest X-ray was normal. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Serum lipase: 

  • Serum lipase is an enzyme that is elevated in acute pancreatitis. Measuring serum lipase levels can help confirm the diagnosis and guide further management. Elevated lipase levels, along with the patient's clinical presentation, would support the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Upper GI endoscopy: Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy is not the immediate next step in this scenario because the patient's symptoms and examination findings suggest pancreatitis rather than an upper gastrointestinal pathology. Pancreatitis should be considered and investigated first.

Option B - Alcohol breath test: An alcohol breath test may be useful in determining recent alcohol consumption. While chronic alcoholism is a risk factor for pancreatitis, a breath test alone would not confirm the diagnosis or guide immediate management. Therefore, the next step in this situation is not the most appropriate one.

Option D - CECT: Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) scan is a valuable diagnostic tool for assessing pancreatic pathology, including pancreatitis. However, in this scenario, the patient's clinical presentation and examination findings strongly suggest acute pancreatitis. Given the typical clinical picture, a serum lipase test would be the more appropriate and efficient next step before considering more invasive imaging studies.

questions.text: Device shown in the image is used for which purpose?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Prevent transfusion related reactions:

  • Leukoreduction filters are designed to remove white blood cells from donated blood products, such as red blood cells or platelets. White blood cells can contribute to transfusion-related reactions, including febrile non-hemolytic reactions, allergic reactions, and some cases of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI). By reducing the number of white blood cells in the transfused blood, leukoreduction filters help minimize the occurrence of these reactions.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Prevent viral infections: While leukoreduction filters can help reduce the risk of certain viral infections to some extent, their primary purpose is not specifically focused on preventing viral infections.

Option C - Prevent infections: The primary goal of leukoreduction filters is to remove white blood cells, which can contribute to transfusion-related reactions, as mentioned earlier.

Option D - All of the above: This option is incorrect because leukoreduction filters primarily target transfusion-related reactions by removing white blood cells.

questions.text: The surgical site infection rate expected in a patient with a clean-contaminated wound that is operated upon after antibiotics prophylaxis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 3%:

  • Clean-contaminated wounds, which have a controlled entry into a normally sterile area (such as the gastrointestinal tract or genitourinary tract) with minimal contamination, carry a higher risk of surgical site infection compared to clean wounds. With the administration of appropriate antibiotic prophylaxis, the expected surgical site infection rate for clean-contaminated wounds is around 3%.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 1-2%:

  • This option suggests a lower range of SSI rates, which is consistent with clean surgeries (1-2%) rather than clean-contaminated surgeries.

Option C - 13-20%:

  • This option indicates a higher range of SSI rates, which is consistent with contaminated surgeries (13-20%) rather than clean-contaminated surgeries.

Option D - 20-30%:

  • This option also indicates a higher range of SSI rates, which is consistent with contaminated surgeries (20-30%) rather than clean-contaminated surgeries.

questions.text: Which of the following does not classify as locally advanced breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tumor less than 4 cm:

  • Locally advanced breast cancer (LABC) typically refers to breast cancer that has spread beyond the breast to nearby tissues but has not yet metastasized to distant organs. Locally advanced breast cancer (LABC) encompasses stages IIIA, IIIB, and IIIC.
  • In the staging of breast cancer, tumor size is an important factor. Generally, tumors larger than 5 cm (T3 or T4 tumors) are considered locally advanced.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Inflammatory breast cancer:

  • The inflammatory breast cancer is classified as stage T4d, equivalent to stage IIIb, indicating its resemblance to locally advanced breast cancer (LABC).

Option C - Chest wall involvement:

  • Involvement of the chest wall by breast cancer (T4) is a criterion for classifying breast cancer as locally advanced.
  • T4 tumors are specifically mentioned as part of Stage III breast cancer.

Option D - Skin involvement:

  • Skin involvement by breast cancer, such as ulceration, edema (including Peau d'orange), or satellite nodules, is another criterion for classifying breast cancer as locally advanced (T4b).
  • T4b tumors are explicitly mentioned as part of Stage III breast cancer.

questions.text: The most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Insulinomas:

  • Insulinomas are the most common neuroendocrine tumors of the pancreas. They arise from insulin-producing cells in the pancreas called beta cells. Insulinomas typically produce excessive amounts of insulin, leading to recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia (low blood sugar). They are usually benign and solitary tumors.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Gastrinoma: Gastrinomas are neuroendocrine tumors that occur in the duodenum or pancreas. They produce excessive amounts of gastrin, leading to a condition called Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. Gastrinomas are typically associated with peptic ulcers and acid hypersecretion rather than being the most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas.

Option B - Somatostatinoma: Somatostatinomas are rare neuroendocrine tumors that can arise in various organs, including the pancreas. These tumors produce excessive amounts of somatostatin, which inhibits the release of multiple hormones. While somatostatinomas can occur in the pancreas, they are relatively rare compared to other neuroendocrine tumors.

Option D - VIPoma: VIPomas, also known as Verner-Morrison syndrome or pancreatic cholera, are neuroendocrine tumors that secrete vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP). These tumors are rare and can occur in the pancreas or other organs. VIPoma is associated with a condition called VIPoma syndrome, which includes symptoms such as severe diarrhea, dehydration, electrolyte imbalances, and flushing.

questions.text: ABCDE rule applies for:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Malignant melanoma:

  • ABCDE rule for malignant melanoma:
    • A - Asymmetry
    • B - Border irregularity
    • C - Color variation
    • D - Diameter (> 6mm)
    • E - Evolution (changes over time)

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B, C & D are incorrect. Refer to explanation of correct option.

questions.text: Which structures are preserved during radical neck dissection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A.

Digastric muscle: This is the correct option. The digastric muscle, which is responsible for opening and closing the jaw, is typically spared during a radical neck dissection. Preserving the digastric muscle helps maintain normal jaw function and prevents complications related to swallowing and speech.

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Sternocleidomastoid muscle: This option is incorrect. The sternocleidomastoid muscle, located on the side of the neck, is often partially or completely removed during a radical neck dissection. Its removal allows access to deeper structures and lymph nodes in the neck, especially in cases where cancer has spread.

Option C. Spinal accessory nerve: This option is incorrect. The spinal accessory nerve (also known as cranial nerve XI) is commonly sacrificed during a radical neck dissection. This nerve innervates the sternocleidomastoid muscle and the trapezius muscle. Sacrificing the spinal accessory nerve can result in shoulder weakness or dysfunction.

Option D. Ipsilateral cervical lymph nodes: This option is incorrect. Ipsilateral cervical lymph nodes, referring to lymph nodes on the same side as the affected neck, are typically removed during a radical neck dissection. The procedure aims to remove the lymph nodes that may contain cancer cells or be at risk of involvement.

questions.text: A child presents with pain and swelling in the right side of his scrotum and testicular torsion is suspected. Which is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Immediate exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side
Immediate exploration on symptomatic side only
Delayed exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side
Delayed exploration on symptomatic side only

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Immediate exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side:

  • Testicular torsion is a surgical emergency that requires prompt intervention. Exploring both the symptomatic and asymptomatic side is recommended because torsion can occur bilaterally or can progress to involve the contralateral testicle. Exploratory surgery allows for immediate assessment of the torsion, detorsion of the affected testicle, and fixation of both testicles to prevent future torsion episodes.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Immediate exploration on the symptomatic side only: While immediate exploration of the symptomatic side is essential, it does not address the potential involvement of the contralateral testicle. Failing to explore the asymptomatic side may lead to delayed identification and management of a potential torsion on that side, which can result in testicular loss.

Option C - Delayed exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side: Delaying exploration increases the risk of irreversible testicular damage due to compromised blood flow. Testicular torsion is a time-sensitive condition, and any delay in surgical intervention can lead to testicular necrosis and loss.

Option D - Delayed exploration on the symptomatic side only: Delaying exploration on the symptomatic side only can result in testicular ischemia and loss. As mentioned earlier, testicular torsion requires immediate surgical intervention to prevent further damage and preserve testicular viability.

questions.text: Which of the following is the principle behind the wound-healing procedure shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Negative pressure wound therapy:

  • NPWT creates a controlled negative pressure environment around the wound, which helps in wound healing through several mechanisms. It promotes wound contraction, reduces edema, enhances blood flow and oxygenation, removes excess fluid and wound exudate, and facilitates the formation of granulation tissue.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Positive pressure wound therapy: Positive pressure wound therapy is not commonly used for wound healing and does not provide the same benefits as NPWT.

Option C - Foam therapy: Foam therapy refers to the use of specialized foam dressings in wound management. While foam dressings can be used in conjunction with NPWT, they are not the principle behind the procedure shown in the image.

Option D - Sponge therapy: Sponge therapy is a vague term and does not specifically describe a recognized wound-healing technique. It is not synonymous with NPWT.

questions.text: A patient with a nodule of the neck presents to the surgery OPD. A Junior resident performs the following method to palpate it. Identify the procedure shown in the video below.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lahey's method:

  • Lahey's method, also known as the Lahey maneuver, is a technique used to palpate a neck nodule. It involves the examiner placing their thumb and index finger on either side of the neck nodule and gently applying pressure while rolling the nodule between their fingers. This maneuver helps to assess the size, shape, consistency, and mobility of the nodule.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Crile's method: Crile's method, also known as the Crile maneuver, is a technique used in thyroid surgery to mobilize the thyroid gland. It involves the surgeon placing their fingers around the thyroid gland and applying gentle upward and downward traction to free it from surrounding structures. This method is not specifically related to palpation of neck nodules.

Option C - Kocher's test: Used to rule out tracheal narrowing

Option D - Pemberton's method: Pemberton's method is a technique used to assess the presence of superior vena cava obstruction. It involves the patient raising their arms above their head for a prolonged period, which leads to facial congestion and respiratory distress if there is an obstruction. This method is not relevant to the palpation of neck nodules.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes with a history of postcoital bleeding and a visible mass seen in cervix per speculum. The next step to be done:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is C: Targeted biopsy

In a 40-year-old woman presenting with postcoital bleeding and a visible mass seen in the cervix, the next step in management would be a targeted biopsy. This procedure involves obtaining a tissue sample from the abnormal area for further evaluation and diagnosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Conisation (cone biopsy) While it may be performed in cases of abnormal findings on a Pap smear or colposcopy, it is not the initial step in this scenario.

Option B: Cryotherapy Cryotherapy involves using extreme cold to destroy abnormal tissue. While it can be used as a treatment option for certain cervical abnormalities, it is not the first step in evaluation. Option D: Pap smear A Pap smear is a screening test used to detect abnormal changes in cervical cells. However, in the case of a visible mass and postcoital bleeding, a targeted biopsy is more appropriate as it provides a specific tissue sample for evaluation.

questions.text: What is the accurate description regarding the physiological alterations in the respiratory system during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is C: FRC (Functional Residual Capacity) decreases.

During pregnancy, there are several changes in the respiratory system to accommodate the needs of both the mother and the developing fetus. One of these changes is a decrease in the FRC, which refers to the volume of air remaining in the lungs at the end of normal expiration.

The decrease in FRC occurs due to a combination of factors. The enlarging uterus pushes against the diaphragm, reducing the available space for lung expansion. Additionally, hormonal changes during pregnancy, particularly the increased levels of progesterone, affect respiratory drive and can lead to a decrease in FRC.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Minute volume decreases by 50%: This statement is incorrect. During pregnancy, the minute volume, which represents the amount of air breathed in one minute, actually increases. The increase in minute volume is primarily due to an increase in tidal volume (the amount of air inhaled and exhaled during normal breathing) rather than an increase in respiratory rate.

Option B: Residual volume increases: This statement is also incorrect. Residual volume refers to the volume of air that remains in the lungs after a maximal exhalation. In pregnancy, residual volume does not typically increase. Instead, it may decrease slightly due to the upward displacement of the diaphragm by the growing uterus.

Option D: Total lung capacity increases: This statement is incorrect as well. Total lung capacity represents the maximum volume of air the lungs can hold. While certain lung volumes and capacities change during pregnancy, such as FRC, total lung capacity generally remains unchanged or may have only a slight increase.

questions.text: What would be the subsequent course of action for a multigravida woman at 33 weeks gestation who complains of epigastric pain, headache, visual symptoms, and has 3+ proteinuria?
questions.solution:
Correct  Option is D:

The next step of management is administration of intravenous MgSO4 (magnesium sulfate).

It acts as an anticonvulsant and helps prevent seizures in women with pre-eclampsia or those at risk of developing eclampsia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Immediate C-section - While delivery is the definitive treatment for pre-eclampsia, in this case, the immediate priority is to stabilize the patient's condition with MgSO4 administration before considering delivery.

Option B: Dexamethasone for fetal lung maturity - Fetal lung maturity is not the primary concern in this situation. The focus is on managing the maternal condition to prevent complications.

Option C: Induction - vaginal delivery - Inducing labor may be considered once the maternal condition is stable, but in the presence of severe pre-eclampsia, MgSO4 administration takes precedence to prevent seizures and manage the condition.

questions.text: Which of the following marked structures is a branch of the internal carotid artery ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1:

  • The structure marked as 1 represents the anterior ethmoidal artery, which is a branch of the ophthalmic artery. The ophthalmic artery is a branch of the internal carotid artery.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - 2: Structure marked as 2 is the Sphenopalatine artery, which is a branch of the maxillary artery. Maxillary artery is a branch of external carotid artery.

Option C - 3: Structure marked as 3 is the greater palatine artery, which is a branch of the maxillary artery.

Option D - 4: Structure marked as 4 is Superior labial artery, it is a branch of the facial artery.Which is also a branch of external carotid artery

questions.text: Which of the following is Hormone replacement therapy not used for?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is B-CAD Prophylaxis:

Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) is not indicated for CAD (Coronary Artery Disease) prophylaxis. HRT refers to the use of hormones, typically estrogen and progesterone, to alleviate symptoms and manage certain conditions related to hormonal imbalances.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Hot flashes - Hormone Replacement Therapy is commonly used to alleviate hot flashes, which are a common symptom of menopause.

Option C: Osteoporosis - Hormone Replacement Therapy can be used to manage osteoporosis, a condition characterized by reduced bone density and increased risk of fractures.

Option D: Premature menopause - Hormone Replacement Therapy may be considered in cases of premature menopause, which occurs before the age of 40, to provide hormonal support and manage associated symptoms.

questions.text: Which structures are left intact during radical neck dissection?
questions.solution:
Correct Ans: B

  • Sublingual gland: The sublingual gland is not removed in a radical neck dissection. Radical neck dissection is a surgical procedure performed to remove lymph nodes and other structures in the neck to treat head and neck cancers. The sublingual gland is located beneath the tongue and is not typically involved in lymph node metastasis or directly affected by head and neck cancers. Therefore, it is preserved during the surgical procedure.

Option A. Tail of parotid: The tail of the parotid gland, which is the largest salivary gland located in the cheek, can be removed in certain cases of radical neck dissection if it is involved by tumour or affected by lymph node metastasis.

Option C. Submandibular gland: The submandibular gland, another salivary gland located beneath the lower jaw, may be removed in specific cases of radical neck dissection if it is involved by tumour or affected by lymph node metastasis.

Option D. Level 2b lymph nodes: Level 2b lymph nodes are typically included in a radical neck dissection. These lymph nodes are in the upper neck region, near the angle of the mandible. They are commonly removed to ensure adequate clearance of lymphatic tissue in cases of head and neck cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following features is not associated with superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Sensorineural hearing loss:

  • Sensorineural hearing loss: Sensorineural hearing loss is not typically associated with superior semicircular canal dehiscence (SSCD) syndrome. SSCD syndrome is a condition characterized by a thinning or absence of the bone that normally covers the superior semicircular canal in the inner ear. The hallmark symptoms of SSCD syndrome are related to vestibulardysfunction rather than hearing loss.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Gaze-dependent nystagmus: Gaze-dependent nystagmus is a characteristic feature of SSCD syndrome. Patients with SSCD may experience nystagmus triggered by specific gaze positions or movements.

Option B - Positive Fistula test: The Fistula test is used to assess the presence of a communication (fistula) between the inner ear and the middle ear. In SSCD syndrome, the Fistula test is often positive, indicating the presence of abnormal sound or pressure transmission between the inner ear and the middle ear.

Option D - Positive Tullio phenomenon: The Tullio phenomenon refers to an increase in vestibular symptoms, such as vertigo or dizziness, in response to loud sounds. It is commonly observed in patients with SSCD syndrome, and a positive Tullo phenomenon is associated with this condition.

questions.text: A patient undergoes surgery of the lateral part of the base of the skull. Postoperatively, the patient presents with aspiration but does not have a change in voice. Which of the following is the likely reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Superior laryngeal nerve injury:

The superior laryngeal nerve (SLN) is a branch of the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X). It has two branches: the internal branch and the external branch.

  • Internal Branch: Provides sensory innervation to the laryngeal mucosa above the vocal folds. Injury to the internal branch can lead to impaired sensation in the larynx but does not affect vocal cord movement.
  • External Branch: Innervates the cricothyroid muscle, which tenses the vocal cords. Damage to the external branch can result in weakness or paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle, leading to changes in voice (hoarseness).

In the given scenario, the patient has aspiration (suggesting impaired sensation and protection of the airway) but no change in voice. This pattern of symptoms indicates injury to the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve. As a result, the patient's laryngeal mucosa above the vocal folds lacks normal sensation, making it difficult to protect against aspiration.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect because they do not explain the specific pattern of symptoms described in the question.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with a history of profuse vaginal discharge. The discharge has a fishy odour. Which of the following best describes the microscopic finding given below?

choices.text: Epithelial cell with bacteria attached on cell surface

questions.solution:
Correct Options is A: Epithelial cell with bacteria attached to the cell surface: It is most likely indicative of a condition called bacterial vaginosis (BV).

One of the hallmark microscopic findings in BV is the presence of clue cells, which are epithelial cells coated with bacteria adhering to their surface. The bacteria seen in BV are typically Gardnerella vaginalis and other anaerobic bacteria.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B: Bacteria engulfed by macrophages: This finding suggests the presence of macrophages, which are immune cells responsible for engulfing and destroying bacteria.

Option C: Neutrophil engulfed bacteria: Neutrophils are another type of immune cell that is commonly involved in fighting bacterial infections.

Option D: Bacteria arranged in clusters: The presence of bacteria arranged in clusters is not characteristic of bacterial vaginosis. This finding could be more suggestive of other bacterial infections, such as group B streptococcal infection or staphylococcal infection, where bacteria tend to form clusters.

questions.text: Anti-D vaccine is not given in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is C: Intrauterine transfusion at 28 weeks: The Anti-D vaccine is not given in this situation to avoid the destruction of the Rh-positive blood cells being transfused. Intrauterine transfusion involves the direct transfusion of Rh-positive blood into the fetus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Amniocentesis at 16 weeks: The Anti-D vaccine can be administered to Rh-negative mothers after amniocentesis to prevent sensitization. This procedure does not involve the direct transfusion of Rh-positive blood.

Option B: Manual removal of placenta: The Anti-D vaccine can be administered to Rh-negative mothers after manual removal of the placenta to prevent sensitization. This procedure does not involve the direct transfusion of Rh-positive blood.

Option D: MTP at 63 days: If the fetus has Rh-positive blood, the Anti-D vaccine should be given to the Rh-negative mother after the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) to prevent sensitization. The administration of the Anti-D vaccine is not contraindicated in this scenario.

questions.text: Which cervical cancer vaccination is preferred for a 16-year-old unmarried female visiting the gynecology OPD?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Gardasil: Gardasil is a vaccine that provides protection against certain strains of the human papillomavirus (HPV), which is a known cause of cervical cancer. It is recommended for both males and females to prevent HPV infection and its associated complications, including cervical cancer.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Biovac, is not a specific vaccine for cervical cancer or HPV. It is important to choose a vaccine specifically designed to target the strains of HPV that are associated with cervical cancer.

Option C: Rabivac, is a vaccine used for the prevention of rabies, not for cervical cancer.

Option D: Tvac, is not a recognized vaccine for cervical cancer or HPV. It is essential to select a vaccine that has been extensively studied and approved for the prevention of cervical cancer.

questions.text: Identify the post-mortem change described below.:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Suggilation:

  • Suggillation, also known as livor mortis or lividity, refers to the discoloration of the skin that occurs after death due to the settling of blood in the dependent areas of the body.

  • This happens because, after death, blood circulation ceases, and gravity causes blood to pool in the lowest parts of the body.

  • This results in a purplish-red or bluish discoloration of the skin in those areas.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tattooing: Tattooing refers to the permanent insertion of ink or pigment into the dermis layer of the skin. It is not a post-mortem change but rather a deliberate form of body modification performed during a person's lifetime.

Option C - Putrefaction: Putrefaction is the process of decomposition of organic matter after death. It involves the breakdown of tissues by bacteria and other microorganisms, leading to the release of foul-smelling gases and the decay of body tissues. While putrefaction is a post-mortem change, it is not the correct option in this case.

Option D - Decomposition: Decomposition refers to the process by which organic substances break down into simpler forms. It includes various chemical and physical changes that occur after death, such as the breakdown of proteins, fats, and carbohydrates. Putrefaction is one of the stages of decomposition. While decomposition is a general term for post-mortem changes, it is not the specific term used to describe the discoloration of the skin seen in suggillation.

questions.text: Identify the plant which produces a deliriant toxin.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Erythroxylum coca:

  • Erythroxylum coca, commonly known as the coca plant, contains the alkaloid cocaine.

  • While cocaine is primarily known as a powerful stimulant, it can induce delirium and hallucinations at high doses or in certain circumstances.

  • Thus, Erythroxylum coca can produce a deliriant effect when consumed in large quantities.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Datura: Datura plants, such as Datura stramonium, are known for producing deliriant toxins. They contain tropane alkaloids like scopolamine, hyoscyamine, and atropine, which are well-known for their deliriant properties. However, Datura is not the correct option in this context.

Option C - Hyoscine: Hyoscine, also known as scopolamine, is an alkaloid found in various plants, including Datura. It is known for its deliriant effects. However, in this question, the correct option is not Hyoscine itself but rather the plant that produces the deliriant toxin.

Option D - Digitalis purpura: Digitalis purpurea, commonly known as foxglove, is not associated with producing deliriant toxins. It contains cardiac glycosides that primarily affect the heart.

questions.text: The given instrument is used in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Cesarean section

The Doyen's retractor is commonly used in cesarean section procedures. Cesarean section, also known as C-section, is a surgical procedure in which a baby is delivered through an incision made in the mother's abdomen and uterus. The Doyen's retractor is designed to hold and retract the edges of the abdominal incision, allowing better visualization and access to the uterus for the surgeon during the procedure.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A:Vaginal hysterectomy: The Doyen's retractor is not typically used in vaginal hysterectomy procedures. Vaginal hysterectomy involves the removal of the uterus through the vagina, and different instruments are usually used for this type of surgery.

Option C: Manchester operation: The Doyen's retractor is not commonly associated with the Manchester operation, which is a specific surgical technique for treating uterine prolapse. Different retractors and instruments may be used in the Manchester operation.

Option D: Fothergill's surgery: Fothergill's surgery, typically performed for anal fistula treatment, does not typically require the use of the Doyen's retractor. Other specialized instruments may be used for this procedure.

questions.text: What is bullet wipe ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Residual from barrel of gun:

  • Bullet wipe refers to the residue or material that is left behind on a target when a bullet passes through it. This residue is primarily composed of substances such as soot, lubricants, and metal particles that are present in the barrel of the gun. 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Blackening: Blackening typically refers to the darkening or discoloration of a surface due to various factors such as oxidation, charring, or exposure to heat.

Option C - Gutter fracture of the skull: Gutter fracture is a term used to describe a specific type of fracture in the skull, characterized by a groove or channel-like indentation.

Option D - Tattooing: Tattooing, in the context of firearms, refers to the deposition of gunpowder particles or other debris onto the skin when a firearm is discharged at close range.

questions.text: Following a fall in the bathroom, an elderly lady is diagnosed with fractured neck of the femur. Which of the following coexisting conditions most likely predisposed to this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Osteoporosis:

  • Osteoporosis is a condition characterized by decreased bone density and increased bone fragility, making individuals more susceptible to fractures, especially in the hip, spine, and wrist. In the case of an elderly lady who experienced a fall and was diagnosed with a fractured neck of the femur (hip fracture), osteoporosis is a likely contributing factor.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Osteopetrosis:Osteopetrosis is a rare genetic disorder characterized by increased bone density and abnormal bone growth. While it can lead to brittle bones and increased risk of fractures, it is a rare condition and not commonly the underlying cause of fractures in elderly individuals following falls.

Option C - Osteoarthritis: Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of cartilage in the joints, it does not directly affect bone density or increase the risk of fractures.

Option D - Osteomalacia: Osteomalacia is a condition characterized by softening of the bones due to vitamin D deficiency or problems with vitamin D metabolism. Osteomalacia is more commonly associated with generalized bone pain, muscle weakness, and fractures in weight-bearing bones.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most specific for ankylosing spondylitis?

choices.text: Costovertebral and costosternal ankylosis may cause restrictive lung disease

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Costovertebral and costosternal ankylosis may cause restrictive lung disease:

  • Costovertebral and costosternal ankylosis may cause restrictive lung disease. The Costovertebral and costosternal ankylosis may cause restrictive lung disease. Trouble breathing as the upper body curves forward and the chest wall stiffens. Severe ankylosing spondylitis can also cause scarring of the lungs (pulmonary fibrosis) and an increased risk of lung infection.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - HLA B37:

  • This is incorrect as HLA B 27 is a genetic marker that is strongly associated with an increased risk of developing ankylosing spondylitis. 

Option C - More common in Females:

  • This option is incorrect as It is more common in More common in males.

Option D - Vertebral Expansion: 

  • This option is incorrect as there is vertebral fusion.

questions.text: Identify the instrument given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Bone Nibbler:

  • The instrument shown in the image is a bone nibbler. Bone nibblers are surgical instruments used for cutting, nibbling, and shaping bone during orthopedic procedures. They have sharp, serrated jaws that allow for precise bone removal or contouring.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Bone Curette: Bone curette is a different instrument used for scraping or scooping out tissue from the bone, typically used in debridement or bone grafting procedures.

Option C - Plate Holding Forceps: Plate holding forceps are specifically designed to hold and manipulate bone plates during orthopedic surgeries.

Option D - Bone Holding Forceps: Bone holding forceps are used to grasp and hold bone fragments in place during reduction and fixation procedures.

questions.text: Which of the following types of toxins has the maximum damage potential?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Corrosive poison

 

Explanation:

 

Corrosive poison has the maximum damage potential among the listed types due to its rapid and extensive destruction of tissues upon contact.

Corrosive poisons (such as strong acids and alkalis) cause immediate and extensive tissue destruction upon contact, leading to severe burns, perforation of the gastrointestinal tract, shock, and potentially rapid death. Their effects are both local (at the site of contact) and systemic due to rapid absorption of toxic byproducts.

 

Irritant poison (Option A): Causes inflammation of mucous membranes (e.g., GI tract), leading to vomiting, diarrhoea, and abdominal pain. Damage is usually localized and less severe than corrosives.

 

Alcohol (Option C): Causes CNS depression, hypoglycaemia, respiratory depression, and liver damage with chronic use. Not as acutely destructive as corrosives.

 

Opioid (Option D): Acts on central opioid receptors, causing respiratory depression and CNS effects. Lethal if untreated, but damage is reversible with prompt treatment (e.g., naloxone).

questions.text:
Match the following poisons and test:


	
		
			
			Column A
			
			
			Column B
			
		
		
			
			1. Marsh test

			2. Silver nitrate paper test

			3. Cavett test

			4. Marquis test
			
			
			A. Opium

			B. Aluminium phosphide

			C. Cyanide

			D. Alcohol

			E. Arsenic
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1-E, 2-B, 3-D, 4-A:

Column A lists the poisons, and Column B lists the corresponding tests. 

  • Marsh test: Marsh test is used to detect the presence of arsenic. It involves generating arsine gas from the sample and using it to produce a characteristic brown or black deposit on a cold surface.

  • Silver nitrate paper test: The silver nitrate paper test is used to detect the presence of cyanide. When exposed to cyanide, the silver nitrate paper turns yellow or brown.

  • Cavett test: The Cavett test is used to detect the presence of alcohol. It involves using potassium dichromate and sulfuric acid to oxidize the alcohol, producing a colour change.

  • Marquis test: Marquis test is used to detect the presence of opium alkaloids. It involves the addition of Marqui's reagent to the sample, resulting in a characteristic color change.

    • It can be used to test cocaine, opiates and phenethylamines.

 Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, & D are incorrect.

questions.text: The test performed in the following image is
questions.solution:
Correct Options A - Allen's Test:

  • Allen's test is performed to assess the patency and adequacy of collateral circulation in the hand. It is typically conducted before arterial puncture or surgical procedures involving the hand.
  • Allen's test: This test involves compressing both the radial and ulnar arteries while the patient clenches and releases their hand. The release of pressure from each artery is done separately to observe the return of colour, indicating the adequacy of collateral circulation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Roos test: The Roos test, also known as the elevated arm stress test, is performed to evaluate thoracic outlet syndrome. It involves asking the patient to open and close their hands rapidly while holding their arms elevated.

Option C - Adson's test: Adson's test is used to assess the presence of thoracic outlet syndrome. It involves palpating the radial pulse while the patient rotates their head and extends their neck.

Option D - Wright test: There is no widely recognized medical test referred to as the "Wright test." It is not a known test in the context of medical examinations or diagnostics.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 28-year-old man who has completed a half-marathon and is now experiencing pain on the front and inner side of his shin that worsens with prolonged jogging and walking? The X-ray results for his leg were normal.
questions.solution:
Correct option is B: Shin splint: Shin splints commonly present with pain along the anterior and medial aspect of the tibia. The pain is often described as a dull, aching sensation and is aggravated by activities such as running or walking for a long time. X-ray findings are usually normal in shin splints.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Jones fracture: Jones fracture refers to a fracture of the fifth metatarsal bone in the foot, typically involving the metaphyseal-diaphyseal junction. It is not related to the symptoms described in the case.

Option C: Lisfranc fracture: Lisfranc fracture involves the injury to the tarsometatarsal joint complex in the midfoot. It is not related to the symptoms described in the case.

Option D: Nutcracker fracture: Nutcracker fracture refers to a fracture of the scaphoid bone in the wrist. It is not related to the symptoms described in the case.

questions.text: The following X-ray shows a lytic lesion of the lower limb. The biopsy shows fibroblastic proliferation, osteoclast and inflammatory cells. From the given options, the most likely diagnosis that can be inferred from the above clinical picture is
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Giant Cell Tumour:

  • The clinical picture described in the question suggests a lytic lesion of the lower limb with histological features of fibroblastic proliferation, osteoclasts, and inflammatory cells. These findings are characteristic of a giant cell tumour. Giant cell tumours are benign but locally aggressive bone tumours that commonly occur in the epiphyseal regions of long bones, including the lower limb. They typically present as lytic lesions on X-ray and are characterized by the presence of multinucleated giant cells along with fibroblasts and inflammatory cells on histopathological examination.

Option A - Aneurysmal Bone Cyst: Aneurysmal bone cysts are typically characterized by blood-filled cystic spaces and are not associated with fibroblastic proliferation or inflammatory cells.

Option C - Chondroblastoma: Chondroblastomas are benign bone tumors composed of chondroblasts and typically present with calcified or ossified areas. They do not exhibit fibroblastic proliferation or osteoclasts.

Option D - Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis: Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is characterized by the presence of Langerhans cells, which are dendritic cells, on histopathological examination. LCH may present with lytic bone lesions, but the presence of fibroblastic proliferation and osteoclasts is not typical for LCH.

questions.text: Given below is the X ray of a newborn. What is the type of scoliosis shown in the X-ray ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Congenital Scoliosis:

  • This type of scoliosis is present at birth and is caused by abnormal spinal development during fetal development.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Postural Scoliosis:

  • Also known as non-structural scoliosis, this type of scoliosis is reversible and typically caused by factors such as poor posture, muscle imbalances, or leg length discrepancy. It does not involve any structural abnormalities of the spine.

Option C - Infantile Scoliosis:

  • This type of scoliosis develops in children younger than three years old. The cause is often unknown, and it can spontaneously resolve or progress over time.

Option D - Degenerative Scoliosis:

  • Also known as adult-onset scoliosis, this type of scoliosis occurs later in life due to degenerative changes in the spine, such as disc degeneration, osteoporosis, or spinal arthritis.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department after he fell on his outstretched hand. An X-ray was performed and is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Galeazzi Fracture:

  • The X-ray provided shows a fracture of the radius along with dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint. This is characteristic of a Galeazzi fracture.
  • Galeazzi fracture involves a fracture of the radius bone along with disruption of the distal radioulnar joint.
  • It typically occurs as a result of a fall with an outstretched hand with an axial load.
  • The fracture pattern involves the junction of the distal and middle third of the radius, while the dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint occurs due to disruption of the interosseous membrane.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Colle's Fracture - Colle's fracture is a fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation. It does not involve dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint.

Option B - Rolando's Fracture - Rolando's fracture is a comminuted fracture of the base of the thumb, typically resulting from high-energy trauma. It is not applicable to the given X-ray.

Option D - Monteggia Fracture - Monteggia fracture is a fracture of the proximal third of the ulna along with dislocation of the radial head. It does not match the findings in the provided X-ray.

questions.text: Identify the following device.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cock-up splint:

  • Cock-up splint is a device used to immobilize and support the wrist in a neutral or slightly extended position. It is typically used for conditions such as carpal tunnel syndrome, wrist sprains, and tendon injuries. The splint extends along the volar aspect of the forearm and supports the wrist in a dorsiflexed position while allowing finger movements.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Colles' cast: Colles' cast is a type of cast used for the treatment of distal radius fractures. It is a circumferential cast that extends from below the elbow to the metacarpal heads, immobilizing the wrist and forearm.

Option C - Knuckle bender splint: Knuckle bender splint is a finger splint used to provide extension support to the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint of the finger.

Option D - Dynamic finger splint: Dynamic finger splint is a splint that allows controlled movement of the finger joints while providing support and protection. It is often used in the rehabilitation of finger injuries or after surgeries.

questions.text:
Evaluate the following statements with respect to CTEV:


	50% cases are in males and are bilateral
	Forefoot is adducted and supinated
	With Ponseti technique, correction rate is upto 90%
	Equinus should be corrected first
questions.solution:
Correct Option B are correct - 1 and 3:

  • Statement 1 is true, as approximately 50% of CTEV cases occur in males and bilateral involvement is common. Statement 3 is also correct, as the Ponseti technique has shown a correction rate of up to 90% for CTEV. Therefore, option B is the correct option

Incorrect Options:
Option A - 1, 2, 3 are correct: This option is incorrect because statement 2 is incorrect. The forefoot in CTEV is adducted (turned inward), but it is not supinated (tilted upward). Instead, the forefoot is usually in a pronated position (tilted downward). Therefore, option A is not the correct option.

Option C - 2 and 4 are correct: This option is incorrect because statement 4 is incorrect. In the treatment of CTEV using the Ponseti technique, the primary focus is on correcting the forefoot adduction, not equinus. Equinus correction comes in later stages of treatment once the forefoot deformity is adequately addressed. Therefore, option C is not the correct option.

Option D - 1, 2, 3, 4 are correct: This option is incorrect because statement 2 is incorrect. The forefoot in CTEV is adducted, not supinated. Therefore, option D is not the correct option.

questions.text: Assertion: As Pott's spine progresses and causes neurological difficulties, decompression surgery becomes necessary.  Why: Neurological abnormalities may persist even after completion of ATT.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is true, but the reason is false
Assertion is false, but the reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.solution:
Correct Option is B: Both the assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion.

  • Assertion: Decompression surgery is needed with progressive neurological difficulty in Pott's spine. This means that when there is a progressive neurological impairment in Pott's spine (spinal tuberculosis), decompression surgery is necessary.
  • Reason: Even after completion of ATT (anti-tuberculosis treatment), there can be neurological abnormalities. This statement is true, as some patients may still experience residual neurological deficits even after completing the anti-tuberculosis treatment.

Incorrect options:

Option A: This option states that both the assertion and reason are true, and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion. However, as explained earlier, the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion.

Option C: This option states that the assertion is true, but the reason is false. However, both the assertion and reason are true, so this option is incorrect.

Option D: This option states that the assertion is false, but the reason is false. However, the assertion is true, so this option is incorrect.

Option E: This option states that both the assertion and reason are false. However, as explained earlier, both the assertion and reason are true, so this option is incorrect.

questions.text: According to the expanded New Ballard score, which of the options listed below is considered a part of the neuromuscular criteria for assessing maturity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C) Scarf sign

 

Explanation:

 

Scarf sign is one of the six neuromuscular maturity criteria in the Expanded New Ballard Score. It assesses passive tone in the shoulder girdle by observing how far the infant’s elbow can be drawn across the chest.

Neuromuscular criteria in the Expanded New Ballard Score:

1. Posture

2. Square window (wrist)

3. Arm recoil

4. Popliteal angle

5. Scarf sign

6. Heel-to-ear

These, together with six physical-maturity signs, allow estimation of gestational age from 20 to 44 weeks with reasonable accuracy.

Heel-knee test (Option A) is incorrect because it is not part of the New Ballard Score; the relevant manoeuvre is heel-to-ear, not heel-to-knee.

Finger-nose test (Option B) is incorrect because it is a cerebellar co-ordination test used in older children/adults, not in neonatal gestational age assessment.

Cubital angle (Option D) is incorrect because the score employs the square-window (wrist) angle and the popliteal angle, but no cubital-angle measurement.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a child (with a history of pharyngitis) who has been experiencing brown-colored urine and reduced urine output for the past three days? The child also exhibits mild swelling in the face and feet, with a blood pressure reading of 126/90. The child has high levels of protein in the urine (2+), more than 100 red blood cells per high power field (HPF), and a few granular casts. Additionally, the child's creatinine level is 0.9 and urea level is 56.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - PSGN:

  • The patient’s presentation with gross hematuria (cola colored urine), proteinuria, and edema is suggestive of nephritic syndrome.
  • PSGN is an immune-mediated glomerular disease that occurs as a result of a preceding streptococcal infection, such as a throat infection or impetigo.
    • Deposition of immune complexes with streptococcal antigen and complement activation.
    • Antibodies against streptococcus cross react with glomerular antigens due to molecular mimicry. 
  • It typically presents with features of nephritic syndrome, including brown-coloured urine, oliguria, facial and pedal edema, and hypertension.
  • Dx: proteinuria, RBC and RBC casts, decreased levels of C3, increased ASO titer following pharyngitis, increased Anti DNase B following pyoderma 
  • Tx: mainly supportive, early antibiotics, diuretics, salt and water restriction

Incorrect Options - Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: What is an indicator of successful neonatal resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Correct option is C - Increased heart rate:

During neonatal resuscitation, assessing the effectiveness of the intervention is crucial. One of the signs of effective resuscitation is an increased heart rate. When successful resuscitation measures are implemented, the newborn's heart rate should improve or increase from its initial low or absent state. The heart rate is a vital indicator of the baby's cardiovascular function and response to resuscitation efforts. Therefore, an increased heart rate indicates improved circulation and response to resuscitative measures.

Option A: Colour change: While colour change can be an important sign during neonatal resuscitation, it alone is not considered a definitive indicator of effective resuscitation. Colour change, such as the transition from cyanosis (bluish discoloration) to normal skin colour, may indicate improved oxygenation but does not necessarily reflect the overall success of resuscitation efforts.

Option B: Bilateral air entry: Bilateral air entry is an important goal during neonatal resuscitation to ensure adequate ventilation and oxygenation. However, it is not a specific sign of effective resuscitation.

Option D: None of the above: This option is incorrect as an increased heart rate is indeed a sign of effective neonatal resuscitation, as explained above.

questions.text: What is the gene associated with Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - GABRA-1: 

  • Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME) is a type of epilepsy that typically begins in adolescence and is characterized by myoclonic seizures, generalized tonic-clonic seizures, and sometimes absence seizures.
  • GABRA-1, refers to the gamma-aminobutyric acid receptor alpha-1 subunit gene.
  • Mutations or variations in this gene have been associated with an increased risk of developing JME.

Incorrect Options - A, C, and D are not associated with juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.

questions.text: Which type of cancer is not linked to viral infection among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D -  Superficial spreading melanoma:

  • Superficial spreading melanoma is a type of skin cancer that primarily occurs due to exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation from the sun or artificial sources, such as tanning beds. It is not directly associated with viral infections like the other options.

Incorrect Option: 

Option A - Kaposi sarcoma- Kaposi sarcoma is caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) infection. It commonly affects individuals with weakened immune systems, such as those with HIV/AIDS.

Option B - Primary effusion lymphoma- Primary effusion lymphoma is associated with human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) infection. It primarily occurs in individuals with compromised immune systems, such as those with HIV/AIDS.

Option C - Merkel cell carcinoma- Merkel cell carcinoma is associated with Merkel cell polyomavirus (MCV) infection. This virus is thought to play a role in the development of Merkel cell carcinoma, a rare and aggressive form of skin cancer.

questions.text: A 5 year old child presents to the OPD with pedal edema and facial puffiness for the past 5 days. BP was 126/80 mm Hg, proteinuria 3+. Urine examination shows 100 RBCs/hpf. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis:

  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is type 3 hypersensitivity reaction followed by group A beta-hemolytic streptococci.
  • It commonly affects children and presents with symptoms such as pedal edema (swelling of the feet), facial puffiness, hypertension (elevated blood pressure), and proteinuria (presence of excess protein in the urine).
  • In PSGN, the immune response triggered by the streptococcal infection causes formation of immune complexes by an antigen called Streptococcal pyrogenic
    exotoxin B (SPEP).
  • This is distributed in the renal parenchyma damagin the blood vessels contributing to liguria, increaased renin (HTN)

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Minimal change disease:

  • Hematuria (presence of RBCs in urine) is less common in minimal change disease, and when present, it's usually microscopic rather than gross.
  • Presents with nephrotic syndrome characterized by proteinuria (typically massive), hypoalbuminemia, and edema.

 

Option C - Membranous glomerulonephritis:

 

  • Presents with nephrotic syndrome but is more common in adults.
  • Proteinuria is usually moderate to severe and may not be accompanied by gross hematuria.
  • Edema and hypertension can be present but are less common in children.

Option D - Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis:

  • Presents with nephrotic syndrome but is also more common in adults.
  • Proteinuria can be massive but is typically accompanied by microscopic hematuria rather than gross hematuria.
  • Edema and hypertension may be present but are less common in children.

questions.text: An infant in the NICU was observed to have the features as seen in the Image below. In addition to these features, there is an audible grunt. What would the Silverman Anderson score be?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 8:

  • The Silverman Anderson score assesses five respiratory parameters: intercostal retractions, xiphoid retractions, substernal retractions, nasal flaring, and expiratory grunt. Each parameter is given a score ranging from 0 to 2, with a higher score indicating more severe respiratory distress. Based on the description provided, if the infant in the image exhibits the features associated with respiratory distress, including an audible grunt, it suggests significant respiratory distress. Therefore, the overall Silverman Anderson score would be higher, such as 8, indicating more severe respiratory distress.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - 6: Option B suggests a Silverman Anderson score of 6. This would indicate a moderate level of respiratory distress. However, based on the description provided, which includes features of respiratory distress and an audible grunt, it suggests a more severe respiratory condition. Therefore, a score of 6 would not accurately reflect the severity of the respiratory distress, making it an incorrect option.

Option C - 5: Option C suggests a Silverman Anderson score of 5. This would indicate a moderate level of respiratory distress. However, given the presence of respiratory distress features and an audible grunt, the infant's condition appears to be more severe. A score of 5 would not adequately represent the severity of the respiratory distress observed, making option C incorrect.

Option D - 4: Option D suggests a Silverman Anderson score of 4, which would indicate mild respiratory distress. However, based on the description provided, including the presence of respiratory distress features and an audible grunt, it suggests a more severe respiratory condition. Therefore, a score of 4 would underestimate the severity of the respiratory distress, making option D incorrect.

questions.text: What is the most common presentation of inhalational anthrax?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hemorrhagic mediastinitis:

  • This is the most common presentation of inhalational anthrax. It is characterized by severe chest pain, shortness of breath, and mediastinal widening on imaging. Hemorrhagic mediastinitis refers to the presence of bleeding and inflammation in the mediastinum, the area between the lungs.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 7-year-old child who complains of leg pain and had a fever and cough three days ago? The calf muscles are tender on palpation, but reflexes and other clinical examinations are normal. Laboratory testing shows CK levels of 2000 IU.
questions.solution:
Correct Option  A - Viral Myositis:

  • The patient’s presentation with leg pain and a history of fever and cough three days ago with tenderness in calf muscles on palpation and increased creatine kinase is suggestive of viral myositis.
  • Viral myositis presents with muscle pain, tenderness, and sometimes swelling.
  • The elevation of creatine kinase (CK) levels in the blood is an indication of muscle damage or breakdown.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Duchenne muscular dystrophy:

  • Duchenne muscular dystrophy is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle weakness and wasting.
  • It usually manifests in early childhood and is not typically associated with a recent history of fever and cough.

Option C - GBS:

  • GBS is an autoimmune disorder affecting the peripheral nervous system.
  • It causes muscle weakness and can lead to paralysis.
  • It is unlikely in this case as there are no signs of neurological involvement or abnormal reflexes.

Option D - Dermatomyositis:

  • Dermatomyositis is an inflammatory muscle disease that primarily affects the skin and muscles.
  • It usually presents with characteristic skin rash along with muscle weakness.
  • The absence of skin rash in this case makes dermatomyositis less likely.

questions.text: A patient from Uttarakhand presented in the month of September with fever and myalgia after a bite with a mite. The patient was started on IV ceftriaxone, but it did not help; later, the patient noticed cutaneous lesions on examination (black eschar), as given below in the figure. What is your diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Scrub Typhus:

  • The patient presenting with fever, myalgia, and cutaneous lesions (black eschar) after a bite with a mite in Uttarakhand during September is suggestive of Scrub typhus.
  • Scrub typhus is a bacterial infection caused by the Orientia tsutsugamushi bacterium. It is transmitted to humans through the bite of infected chiggers (larva of trombiculid mites) found in areas with dense vegetation. Scrub typhus is commonly seen in rural areas, particularly in regions with heavy vegetation, such as forests or grasslands.
  • The clinical presentation of scrub typhus includes fever, headache, myalgia (muscle pain), and a characteristic eschar at the site of the chigger bite. The eschar is a black, necrotic lesion surrounded by an area of inflammation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Murine Typhus: Murine typhus is caused by the bacteria Rickettsia typhi, transmitted to humans by rubbing or inhalation of the feces of infected fleas. It typically presents with fever, headache, myalgia, anorexia, and rash (involving the trunk more often than the extremities).

Option C - Q Fever: Q fever is caused by the bacteria Coxiella burnetii, transmitted to humans through ingestion of contaminated milk or by handling wools, hides or meat. It can cause a flu-like illness, hepatitis, meningoencephalitis or endocarditis.

Option D - Louse Borne Typhus: Louse-borne typhus also known as epidemic typhus, is caused by the bacteria Rickettsia prowazekii and is transmitted to humans through rubbing of louse (Pediculus humanus corporis) feces on an abraded skin. It presents with high fever, headache, and rash starting from trunk and spreading to limbs.

questions.text: The following device shown attached to the baby is used in all except:
questions.solution:
Correct option is D: Measure central cyanosis:

  • Pulse oximeters are not used to directly measure central cyanosis, which refers to the bluish discoloration of the central parts of the body due to decreased oxygenation.
  • Pulse oximeters primarily measure peripheral oxygen saturation levels by detecting the amount of oxygen-bound hemoglobin in the blood.

Incorrect options: Pulse oximeters are used in options A, B, and C.

questions.text: Which of the following is a subcutaneous fungal agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Sporothrix Schenckii:

  • Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus that causes sporotrichosis, a subcutaneous fungal infection. Sporotrichosis typically presents as nodules or ulcers along the lymphatic channels and is commonly acquired through traumatic inoculation of the fungus, such as by thorns or splinters.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cryptococcus Neoformans: Cryptococcus neoformans is a fungal pathogen primarily associated with respiratory and central nervous system infections in immunocompromised individuals. It is classified as an opportunistic infection.

Option B - Histoplasma Capsulatum: It is a dimorphic fungus that causes histoplasmosis. Histoplasmosis is an intracellular infection of the reticuloendothelial system. It is classified under systemic mycoses.

Option D - Talaromyces Marneffei: It is a dimorphic fungus that causes opportunistic infections in an individual infected with AIDS. It causes a disseminated infection with multiple organ involvement. It is classified as an opportunistic infection.

questions.text:
Assertion: Antibiotics should not be given to children having diarrhea

Reason: Diarrhea in children is mostly caused by viruses

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are correct and reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both assertion and reason are correct and reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is independently a correct statement but the reason is false
Assertion is false but the reason is correct statement
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.solution:
Correct Option is A - Both assertion and reason are correct and reason is the correct explanation of the assertion.

  • This option is correct because both the assertion and reason are accurate, and the reason provided explains why the assertion is true.
  • Antibiotics should not be given to children with diarrhea because most cases of diarrhea in children are caused by viruses, not bacteria.
  • Therefore, giving antibiotics to children with viral diarrhea would be ineffective and potentially harmful.

Incorrect Options - B, C, D and E are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: Following vector is not involved in transmission of which of the following disease ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Kyasanur Forest Disease:

  • The vector shown in the image is a sandfly. Points for identification.
    • Light or dark brown flies, smaller than mosquitoes.
    • Body and wings covered by dense hair.
    • Head contains a pair of long, slender, and hairy antennae, palpi, and a proboscis.
    • Thorax contains a pair of wings and three pairs of legs.
  • Diseases caused by sandflies are Kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), Sandfly fever, Oriental sore, and Oroya fever.
  • Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD), also known as monkey fever, is caused by the Kyasanur Forest Disease virus (KFDV). Hard ticks are the main vectors involved in the transmission of Kyasanur Forest Disease.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. These diseases are transmitted by sandfly.

questions.text: Which of the following options encompasses the term "Malarial vector indices"?   	Human blood index 	Biting density 	Slide positivity rate 	Inoculation rate
questions.solution:
Correct Ans: B

  • B is the correct answer: 1 and 3 include "Malarial vector indices.
  • Malarial vector indices are parameters used to assess the transmission intensity and risk of malaria in a specific area. They provide information about the behaviour and abundance of mosquito vectors and their potential to transmit the malaria parasite.
  • Human blood index: The human blood index is a measure of the proportion of blood meals taken by mosquitoes from humans. It indicates the preference of mosquitoes to feed on humans, which is crucial for malaria transmission.
  • Slide positivity rate: The slide positivity rate is the percentage of blood slides examined under a microscope that show the presence of malaria parasites. It is an indicator of the prevalence of malaria infections in the population and reflects the intensity of transmission.

Incorrect options:

Option A.  is incorrect because it includes all four options, but only options 1 and 3 are considered as malarial vector indices.

Option C. is incorrect because it includes options 2 and 4, but neither of them is considered as a malarial vector index.

Option D.  is incorrect because it includes options 1, 2, and 4, but option 2 is not considered as a malarial vector index.

questions.text: Malarial control means :

choices.text: To reduce the disease so that it is not public health problem
To reduce the mortality to zero
To prevent local transmission for 3 days

questions.solution:
Correct Ans: A

  • Malarial control means to reduce the disease so that it is not a public health problem.
  • Malarial control refers to the efforts and strategies aimed at reducing the burden of malaria and its impact on public health. The ultimate goal of malarial control is to eliminate malaria as a public health problem. This involves reducing the number of malaria cases to a level where it no longer poses a significant threat to the population.

Incorrect options:

Option B. "To reduce the mortality to zero," focuses specifically on reducing the number of deaths caused by malaria. While reducing malaria-related mortality is an important aspect of malarial control, it does not encompass the entirety of the control measures. C.

Option C. "To prevent local transmission for 3 days," is a limited objective and does not encompass the broader goal of malarial control. Malaria control efforts aim to achieve sustained and long-term reductions in transmission, not just for a short period of time. D.

Option D. "To reduce indices to zero," is not a comprehensive description of malarial control. Malarial vector indices, such as mosquito density and parasite prevalence, are important indicators used to monitor and guide control efforts, but reducing these indices to zero may not always be achievable or necessary for effective control.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a side effect of salbutamol?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is D: Hypoglycemia: Salbutamol, also known as albuterol, is a bronchodilator commonly used to treat asthma and other respiratory conditions. While it has several potential adverse effects, hypoglycemia is not typically associated with salbutamol use.

Hypoglycemia, or low blood sugar levels, is not a commonly reported adverse effect of salbutamol. It primarily acts on beta-2 adrenergic receptors in the lungs and has minimal effect on blood glucose levels.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A: Tachycardia: Salbutamol can cause an increase in heart rate (tachycardia) as it acts on beta-2 adrenergic receptors, which are present in the heart.

Option B: Tolerance: Prolonged use of salbutamol can lead to the development of tolerance, meaning that the body may become less responsive to the medication's effects over time. This may require adjustments in the dosage or additional medications.

Option C: Hypokalemia: Salbutamol can cause a decrease in serum potassium levels (hypokalemia) due to its stimulation of beta-2 adrenergic receptors, which can lead to increased cellular uptake of potassium.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the influenza virus is false?

choices.text: Intranasal Live attenuated vaccine is used
5-12 years is a High Risk Group

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 5-12 years is a High Risk Group:

  • The high-risk groups for severe complications of influenza typically include young children (especially those under 2 years), the elderly (65 years and older), pregnant women, individuals with underlying health conditions, and immunocompromised individuals. The age group of 5-12 years is generally considered to have a lower risk compared to these high-risk groups.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Secondary Attack rate is 5-15%: The secondary attack rate refers to the proportion of susceptible individuals who develop the disease after being exposed to an infected individual. In the case of influenza, the secondary attack rate can vary depending on factors such as the specific strain, population density, and level of immunity. Generally, the secondary attack rate for influenza is estimated to be around 5 to 15%.

Option B - Intranasal Live Attenuated Vaccine is used: Intranasal live attenuated vaccine, a trivalent vaccine H1N1 (A), H3N2 (A), type B is indicated for individuals with influenza infection, contraindicated in low immunity.

Option D - Aquatic Birds act as Reservoir: Aquatic birds, particularly wild waterfowl, are considered the natural reservoir for influenza viruses. They can carry different strains of influenza viruses, including avian influenza viruses, without showing symptoms. These viruses can occasionally cross over to infect other species, including humans.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is irreversible step in gluconeogenesis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Pyruvate kinase:

  • Pyruvate kinase is not directly involved in gluconeogenesis. It catalyzes the conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP) to pyruvate in the final step of glycolysis, which is the breakdown of glucose to produce energy.

Incorrect Option 

Option A - Pyruvate carboxylase:
