  • Pyruvate carboxylase is an enzyme that plays a key role in gluconeogenesis. It catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, which is an important intermediate in the gluconeogenesis pathway.

Option B - Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxylase:

  • Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxylase is also involved in gluconeogenesis. It catalyzes the conversion of oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP), another crucial intermediate in the gluconeogenesis pathway.

Option D - Glucose-6-phosphatase:

  • Glucose-6-phosphatase is an enzyme that is essential for gluconeogenesis. It catalyzes the hydrolysis of glucose-6-phosphate to produce glucose, which can be released into the bloodstream.

questions.text: Propranolol is drug of choice for:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Ulcerated infantile hemangioma:

  • Propranolol is the drug of choice for ulcerated infantile hemangioma.

  • Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker that has been found to be highly effective in treating ulcerated infantile hemangiomas, which are benign tumors of blood vessels that commonly occur in infants. Propranolol helps to reduce the size and improve the appearance of the hemangioma by causing vasoconstriction and reducing blood flow to the affected area. It also promotes the regression of the abnormal blood vessels.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Lymphangioma circumscriptum: Lymphangiomas are malformations of the lymphatic vessels, and propranolol is not the drug of choice for this condition. Propranolol has no effect on lymphatic system. Surgical excision or other treatment modalities may be employed.

Option C - Capillary malformation: Propranolol is not the primary treatment for capillary malformations. Other treatment options, such as laser therapy, may be considered.

Option D - Pyogenic granuloma: Pyogenic granuloma is a benign vascular lesion that typically occurs on the skin or mucous membranes. Propranolol is not commonly used as a first-line treatment for this condition, and other treatments, such as surgical excision or cauterization, may be more appropriate.

questions.text: Identify the drug categorized as schedule X from the options provided.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is C: Ketamine: Ketamine is classified as a Schedule X drug in some countries. Schedule X is a category used to regulate drugs with a high potential for abuse and dependence. These drugs are subject to stricter controls and regulations due to their potential risks and misuse.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A: Halothane: Halothane is a volatile inhalation anaesthetic and is not classified as a Schedule X drug. It is commonly used for general anaesthesia in surgical procedures.

Option B: Thalidomide: Thalidomide is not classified as a Schedule X drug. It is a medication with various uses, including treating certain cancers and skin conditions, but it is also known for its historical association with birth defects when used during pregnancy.

Option D: Colistin: Colistin is an antibiotic primarily used for the treatment of multidrug-resistant bacterial infections. It is not classified as a Schedule X drug.

questions.text: What is pegloticase used for ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is A: A Pegloticase is used for the treatment of chronic gout. It is specifically indicated for patients with severe gout who have not responded well to other treatments or who cannot tolerate other treatment options. Pegloticase works by breaking down uric acid, which helps to reduce the build-up of uric acid crystals in the joints and alleviate symptoms of gout.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B: Rheumatoid arthritis is not a indicated use for pegloticase. Rheumatoid arthritis is a different autoimmune condition that requires different treatment approaches.

Option C: Psoriatic arthritis is also not an indicated use for pegloticase. Psoriatic arthritis is a type of arthritis associated with psoriasis and requires specific treatments targeting both the joint inflammation and skin manifestations.

Option D: Paralytic ileus is a condition characterized by the impairment of intestinal motility, and pegloticase is not indicated for its treatment. Paralytic ileus usually requires supportive care and addressing the underlying cause of the condition.

questions.text: What is one of the measures taken to manage atonic postpartum hemorrhage (PPH)?   	Uterine massage is first step in the management 	Ergometrine is administered in all patients 	Manual removal of placenta is done 	B-Lynch suture is put if medical management fails
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  • 1 & 4 are correct: This option is correct. Uterine massage is indeed the first step in the management of atonic PPH as it helps stimulate uterine contractions. If medical management fails to control the bleeding, the B-Lynch suture can be performed. The B-Lynch suture is a surgical technique where a non-absorbable suture is placed around the uterus to compress it and control bleeding.

Incorrect option:

Option A. 1 & 2 are correct: This option is incorrect. Although uterine massage is an important initial step in the management of atonic postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), the administration of ergometrine (also known as ergonovine) is not recommended in all patients with atonic PPH. Ergometrine is a uterotonic medication that helps in contracting the uterus, but it has side effects and contraindications, such as hypertension, which can limit its use.

Option C. 2 & 4 are correct: This option is incorrect. While the administration of ergometrine can be considered in the management of atonic PPH, it is not universally administered in all patients. The decision to use ergometrine depends on various factors, including the patient's medical history, blood pressure, and potential contraindications. Option 4 is correct because the B-Lynch suture can be considered if medical management fails.

Option D. 2 & 3 are correct: This option is incorrect. Although the administration of ergometrine can be considered in the management of atonic PPH, manual removal of the placenta is not a specific management step for atonic PPH. Manual removal of the placenta may be necessary

questions.text:
Assertion: In pregnancy, the definition of anemia is based on a higher cutoff of hemoglobin (Hb) compared to non-pregnant scenarios

Reason: Physiological hemodilution is seen in pregnancy

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is true, but the reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false
The assertion is false but reason is true

questions.solution:
Correct Ans: A.

  • Both assertion and reason are true, and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion: This option is correct. In pregnancy, the definition of anemia is based on a higher cutoff of hemoglobin (Hb) compared to non-pregnant scenarios. Physiological hemodilution is a normal occurrence during pregnancy, where the blood volume expands more than the increase in red blood cell mass, leading to a relative dilution of the red blood cells. As a result, the Hb concentration may decrease slightly in pregnancy without indicating pathology. To account for this, higher cutoff values for Hb are used to define anemia during pregnancy compared to non-pregnant individuals.

Incorrect option:

Option B. Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion: This option is incorrect. The reason provided, which is physiological hemodilution in pregnancy, is indeed the correct explanation for the assertion. Therefore, Option B is not the correct answer.

Option C. Assertion is true, but the reason is false: This option is incorrect. The assertion is true since a higher cutoff of Hb is used to define anemia in pregnancy. However, the reason is also true because physiological hemodilution is a well-recognized phenomenon during pregnancy.

Option D. Both assertion and reason are false: This option is incorrect. Both the assertion and reason are true, so Option D is not the correct answer.

Option E. The assertion is false, but the reason is true: This option is incorrect. The assertion is actually true since a higher cutoff of Hb is used to define anemia in pregnancy. Therefore, Option E is not the correct answer.

questions.text: Non – pulsatile dose of GnRH agonist is used in all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B-Male infertility:

  • Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists are commonly used in various medical conditions. These medications work by suppressing the release of gonadotropins, which are hormones that stimulate the production of sex hormones in the body. In certain conditions, a non-pulsatile dose of GnRH agonist is used, meaning a continuous or sustained dose is administered.

Incorrect Option:

Option A. Endometriosis: The non-pulsatile dose of GnRH agonist helps suppress the production of estrogen and provides relief from pain and other symptoms associated with endometriosis.

Option C. Precocious puberty: The continuous or non-pulsatile administration of GnRH agonist helps suppress the premature release of sex hormones and slows down the progression of puberty.

Option D. Carcinoma prostate: The non-pulsatile dose of GnRH agonist is used to maintain a continuous suppression of testosterone levels and inhibit the growth of prostate cancer.

questions.text:
Assertion: Hot flushes are common after menopause

Reason: Hot flushes are because of low estrogen or its fluctuatio

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is true, but the reason is false
Assertion is false, but the reason is true
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A

  • Both assertion and reason are true, and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion: This option is correct. Hot flushes are indeed common after menopause. During menopause, the levels of estrogen fluctuate and eventually decrease, leading to hormonal imbalances. The decrease in estrogen is considered the primary cause of hot flushes. Therefore, the reason provided accurately explains the assertion.

Incorrect option:

Option B, C, and D: These options are incorrect

questions.text: Which of the following should be avoided in a 23 years old second gravida with DVT who is already on warfarin ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A. LNG IUCD is a form of intrauterine contraceptive device that releases the hormone levonorgestrel. This hormone can potentially increase the risk of blood clots, and therefore, it is generally not recommended for individuals with a history of DVT or those who are already on anticoagulant therapy like warfarin.

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Progesterone-only pills: Progesterone-only pills, also known as mini-pills, contain only progestin and not estrogen. They are generally considered safe for individuals with a history of DVT.

Option C. Implanon: Implanon is a contraceptive implant that releases etonogestrel, a form of progestin. Similar to progesterone-only pills, etonogestrel-containing implants are generally considered safe for individuals with a history of DVT.

Option D. Depo-Provera: Depo-Provera is a progestin-only injectable contraceptive. Similar to progesterone-only pills and etonogestrel implants, it is generally considered safe for individuals with a history of DVT.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent classifications of trophoblasts penetrate spiral arterioles?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A. Extravillous

Extravillous trophoblasts are specialized cells in the placenta that invade the maternal decidua and myometrium. They play a crucial role in the establishment of maternal-fetal circulation. These trophoblasts penetrate the spiral arterioles in the decidua and myometrium, converting them into low-resistance vessels that supply the intervillous space, ensuring adequate blood flow to the placenta for fetal nourishment and oxygen exchange. This invasion of extravillous trophoblasts is essential for the success of pregnancy and proper development of the placenta.

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Endovascular: Endovascular trophoblasts refer to the subtype of extravillous trophoblasts that invade and modify the walls of spiral arteries in the maternal decidua and myometrium. This invasion leads to the conversion of high-resistance, muscular spiral arteries into low-resistance, dilated vessels. This modification ensures adequate maternal blood flow to the placental intervillous space, providing essential nutrients and oxygen to the developing fetus.

Option C. Tertiary villus: Tertiary villi represent the terminal stage of villous development in the placenta, characterized by mature capillaries surrounded by syncytiotrophoblasts. They do not specifically penetrate spiral arterioles.

Option D. Interstitial: Interstitial trophoblasts are found within the placental tissue but are not primarily involved in modifying maternal blood vessels. They are important for placental development and tissue integrity.

The modification of spiral arterioles by extravillous trophoblasts, specifically the endovascular subtype, is critical for ensuring proper maternal-fetal blood exchange and supporting a healthy pregnancy.

questions.text: A diabetic female while delivering the baby only the head came out but even after one minute the shoulder was not delivered. Which of the following should be done ?
questions.solution:
Correct Ans: B

  • McRoberts maneuver: This option is correct. The McRoberts maneuver is a technique used to resolve shoulder dystocia, a condition where the baby's shoulder becomes impacted behind the mother's pubic bone after the delivery of the head. The McRoberts maneuver involves flexing the mother's legs sharply toward her abdomen, which helps to increase the angle of the pelvis and create more space for the shoulders to pass through the birth canal.

Incorrect Option:

Option A. Cleidotomy: This option is incorrect. Cleidotomy is a surgical procedure involving the cutting of the fetal collarbone (clavicle) to facilitate delivery of the shoulders in cases of shoulder dystocia. However, it is not the recommended first-line maneuver in the scenario described.

Option C. C-section: This option is incorrect. While a C-section may be necessary in cases of prolonged shoulder dystocia or if other maneuvers fail to release the impacted shoulder, it is not the first-line intervention in this scenario where only one minute has passed after the delivery of the baby's head.

Option D. Lateral traction: This option is incorrect. Lateral traction is a technique used to apply gentle, controlled pressure on the fetal head during delivery to facilitate the delivery of the shoulders. However, in the scenario described, where the shoulder has not been delivered after one minute, the McRoberts maneuver is a more appropriate initial maneuver to attempt before resorting to other interventions.

questions.text: What is the preferred diagnostic test for vesicovaginal fistula?
questions.solution:
The preferred diagnostic test for vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) is Option B. Cystoscopy.

Explanation:

Option A. IVP (Intravenous Pyelogram): IVP is an imaging test used to visualize the urinary tract, including the kidneys, ureters, and bladder. While it can help identify certain abnormalities, it is not the primary diagnostic test for vesicovaginal fistula. VVF involves an abnormal connection between the bladder and the vagina, which is best visualized directly.

Option B. Cystoscopy: Cystoscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing vesicovaginal fistula. During cystoscopy, a thin tube with a camera (cystoscope) is inserted into the bladder through the urethra. This procedure allows direct visualization of the interior of the bladder. In cases of vesicovaginal fistula, the abnormal opening between the bladder and the vagina can be observed, confirming the diagnosis.

Option C. 3 Swab Test: There is no standard medical test referred to as the "3 Swab Test." It does not pertain to the diagnosis of vesicovaginal fistula or any specific medical condition.

Option D. X-ray: X-rays are not typically used for diagnosing vesicovaginal fistula. X-rays provide a two-dimensional image and may not provide the detailed information necessary to confirm the presence of the fistula between the bladder and the vagina.

questions.text: Which of the following GPCRs does not act via the K+ channel?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Angiotensin 1 receptor:

  • The angiotensin 1 receptor is a G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) that does not directly act via a K+ channel. Activation of the angiotensin 1 receptor by angiotensin II leads to intracellular signaling through G proteins and subsequent activation of downstream pathways, such as the phospholipase C (PLC) pathway and the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway. These pathways result in various cellular responses, including vasoconstriction, aldosterone release, and increased blood pressure regulation. While these pathways can indirectly influence ion channels and cellular activity, they don't directly modulate K+ channels.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Muscarinic M2 receptor: The muscarinic M2 receptor is a GPCR that primarily acts via the activation of K+ channels. When activated by acetylcholine, the M2 receptor initiates a signaling cascade that involves the beta-gamma subunits of G proteins binding to and activating K+ channels, leading to hyperpolarization of the cell membrane and a decrease in heart rate.

Option C - Dopamine D2 receptor: The dopamine D2 receptor is also a GPCR that primarily acts by inhibiting adenylyl cyclase activity, reducing cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels, and indirectly modulating ion channels and cellular responses. While the D2 receptor's activation can have effects on ion channels, it doesn't directly act on K+ channels.

Option D - Serotonin 5 HT 1 receptor: The serotonin 5-HT1 receptor is a GPCR that can have various effects, including modulation of ion channels and second messenger pathways. Similar to the other receptors mentioned, it doesn't directly act via K+ channels.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient who experiences excessive menstrual bleeding and exhibits the following finding during hysteroscopy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D-Submucosal fibroid:

  • Submucosal fibroid: This is the correct option for the given finding. Submucosal fibroids are benign growths that develop within the uterine wall and protrude into the uterine cavity. They can cause heavy menstrual bleeding, as seen in the patient described in the question.
  • They are classified as Type 0 under FIGO classification.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Asherman syndrome: Asherman syndrome is characterized by intrauterine adhesions or scar tissue that can develop following uterine surgery or infection.

Option B. Cervical carcinoma: Cervical carcinoma refers to cancerous growth in the cervix. Hysteroscopy primarily evaluates the uterine cavity, not the cervix.

Option C. Endometrial carcinoma: Endometrial carcinoma is cancer that develops in the lining of the uterus (endometrium).

questions.text: What can be anticipated in angiography as a result of the lesion observed in the image, when a patient exhibits painless reduction in vision and metamorphopsia?
questions.solution:
Correct option D.

  • Double circulation: This term is used to describe the characteristic angiographic appearance of choroidal melanoma. It refers to the presence of two vascular networks within the tumor: an outer network supplying the tumor mass and an inner network supplying the optic nerve head. This finding is typically seen on angiography in cases of choroidal melanoma.

Incorrect option:

Option A. Smoke-stack appearance: This term is commonly associated with retinal vein occlusion, where the veins appear dilated and tortuous, resembling a smoke-stack. It is not a characteristic finding in choroidal melanoma.

Option B. Inkblot appearance: This term is used to describe the appearance of choroidal neovascularization (CNV) in age-related macular degeneration (AMD). It refers to the leakage of dye from the abnormal blood vessels, resulting in irregular-shaped areas of hyperfluorescence on angiography. It is not a characteristic finding in choroidal melanoma.

Option C. Collarstud appearance: This term is used to describe the appearance of retinal capillary hemangioma on angiography. It refers to the early hyperfluorescence surrounding the tumor, resembling a collar around a stud. It is not a characteristic finding in choroidal melanoma.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency and his ocular examination reveals the following. Which of the following is not done initially?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Removal of the foreign body:

  • Removal of the foreign body: This is not done initially, especially in cases of penetrating injuries. The foreign body should be left in place until the patient is taken to an appropriate medical facility with the necessary equipment and expertise to handle such cases.
  • Removal of the penetrating foreign body can result in the drainage of the aqueous humor.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. These the primary test done initially for checking the degree of damage.

questions.text: What should be the initial course of action for a 2-year-old child displaying inward deviation of both eyes?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Refractive error testing:

  • The inward deviation of both the eyes in a 2-year-old child is suggestive of convergent squint due to accommodative esotropia.
  • Refractive accommodative esotropia is the most common cause of convergent squint in the age of 2 to 3 years.
  • Refractive error can cause strabismus (eye misalignment) and may contribute to the medial deviation of both eyes in this case. Therefore, the first step would be to evaluate the child's refractive error through appropriate testing.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. These tests will not be useful to diagnose the cause of esotropia.

questions.text: At what point would you suggest conducting a dilated fundus examination for a person diagnosed with diabetes on their 45th birthday?

choices.text: When the complains of decrease in vision

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Immediately:

  • A dilated fundus examination is recommended immediately as part of the initial evaluation for a person diagnosed with diabetes because of the delayed diagnosis commonly associated with type 2 diabetes.. This examination allows for the assessment of the retina and blood vessels in the eyes to detect any signs of diabetic retinopathy, a common complication of diabetes.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: Which of the following causes an increase in ACh release from the presynaptic neuron?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Potassium channel blocker:

  • Potassium channel blockers inhibit potassium efflux, prolonging action potential duration.
  • This increases calcium influx, enhancing acetylcholine (ACh) release.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C & D: Sodium channel blocker, Calcium channel blocker & Chlorine channel blocker:   

  • Sodium and Chlorine channel blockers, don't directly affect ACh release.
  • Calcium channel blockers reduce calcium influx, potentially decreasing ACh release.

questions.text: A patient with a history of diabetes and hypertension underwent fundus fluorescent angiography (FFA) to evaluate his decreasing vision. The FFA yields an image as shown below, which is characteristic of :
questions.solution:
Correct option A

  • Macular ischemia: This is the correct answer. Macular ischemia refers to the inadequate blood supply to the macula, which is the central part of the retina responsible for central vision. An enlarged foveal avascular zone, as seen in the image, is a sign of reduced blood flow and oxygen delivery to the macula.

Incorrect option:

Option B. Macular edema: Macular edema is the accumulation of fluid in the macula, causing swelling and distortion of the central vision. It is not specifically indicated by the image of an enlarged foveal avascular zone.

Option C. Submacular hemorrhage: Submacular hemorrhage refers to bleeding underneath the macula, which can cause sudden and severe vision loss. It is not indicated by the image provided.

Option D. Premacular hemorrhage: Premacular hemorrhage refers to bleeding within the macula itself. It can cause acute vision loss, but it is not indicated by the image showing an enlarged foveal avascular zone.

questions.text: Apart from mu-opioid receptors, on which other receptor does tramadol act?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Serotonergic and norepinephrine reuptake inhibition:

  • Tramadol acts as a serotonergic and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor. Tramadol is a centrally acting analgesic that primarily binds to mu-opioid receptors to exert its pain-relieving effects. However, in addition to its opioid activity, tramadol also has the ability to inhibit the reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine. By inhibiting the reuptake of these neurotransmitters, tramadol increases their availability in the synaptic cleft, leading to enhanced analgesic effects. This dual mechanism of action contributes to tramadol's unique pharmacological profile.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Anticholinergic: Tramadol does not have anticholinergic activity. Anticholinergic drugs act by blocking the effects of acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors and are not relevant to tramadol's mechanism of action.

Option B - 5HT 1a inhibition: Tramadol does not directly inhibit 5HT1a receptors. While it does affect serotonin levels through its reuptake inhibition, it is not specific to 5HT1a receptors.

Option D - Antihistaminic: Tramadol does not possess significant antihistaminic activity. Antihistaminic drugs act by blocking the effects of histamine at histamine receptors and are not relevant to tramadol's mechanism of action.

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be used to decrease intraocular pressure in glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Dexamethasone:

  • Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid medication that is not typically used to decrease intraocular pressure in glaucoma. While corticosteroids can have anti-inflammatory effects and may be used in certain ocular conditions, they are not commonly prescribed as primary treatments for reducing intraocular pressure in glaucoma.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Acetazolamide: Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that can effectively lower intraocular pressure in glaucoma. It reduces the production of aqueous humour, thereby decreasing the pressure inside the eye.

Option C - Apraclonidine: Apraclonidine is an alpha-adrenergic agonist that can be used to reduce intraocular pressure in glaucoma. It works by decreasing the production of aqueous humour and increasing the outflow of fluid from the eye.

Option D - Mannitol: Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that is sometimes used in acute glaucoma episodes to rapidly reduce intraocular pressure. It works by drawing fluid out of the eye, thereby lowering the pressure.

questions.text: The function of the Golgi tendon organ is to ___________

choices.text: Sense changes in position of the muscle
Sense changes in length of the muscl

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Sense Changes in Muscle Tension:

  • The Golgi tendon organ, located within the muscle tendon, senses changes in muscle tension or force generated during muscle contraction. It provides information to the central nervous system about the level of tension in the muscle.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, C, and D: They are not the main role of the Golgi tendon organ.

questions.text: Z track technique is used for?

choices.text: Administration of long acting depot antipsychotics

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Administration of long-acting depot antipsychotics: 

  • The Z-track technique is a method used for the administration of certain medications, particularly long-acting depot formulations. It involves pulling the skin and underlying tissue to one side before injecting the medication into a deep muscle, and then releasing the skin after the injection is complete. This technique helps to create a zig-zag or "Z" path for the medication, preventing leakage or tracking of the medication along the injection site.

  • The Z-track technique is specifically used for medications that may cause skin staining or irritation or have a potential for leakage. Long-acting depot antipsychotics, such as haloperidol decanoate or fluphenazine decanoate, are commonly administered using the Z-track technique to ensure proper delivery of the medication into the muscle and minimize skin irritation or discoloration.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Administration of nicotine patches: Nicotine patches are typically applied to the skin using a different technique, usually adhering to the manufacturer's instructions for application.

Option B - Monitoring of carbamazepine therapy: Carbamazepine therapy typically involves monitoring blood levels of the medication and adjusting the dosage as needed but does not require the Z-track technique for administration.

Option D - Monitoring of lithium therapy: Lithium therapy is usually orally administered. Z track is for IM injections.

questions.text: Pacemaker generating the rhythm for breathing is ______________

choices.text: Dorsal group of neurons in the medulla

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Pre-Botziger complex:

  • The Pre-Botzinger complex, located in the medulla oblongata, is considered the primary pacemaker for spontaneous breathing. It consists of I (inspiratory) and E (Expiratory) neurons that spontaneously generate rhythmic signals, initiating the pattern of breathing.  

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pneumotaxic centre: The pneumotaxic center, located in the pons of the brainstem, helps regulate the duration and depth of each breath. It controls the switching off of the inspiratory phase, allowing for smoother transitions between inhalation and exhalation.

Option B - Botzinger complex: It contains the expiratory group of neurons, and their main role is to control the expiration.

Option D - Apneustic center: The apneustic center, located in the lower pons of the brainstem, is involved in regulating the intensity and duration of inhalation through inhalatory neuron.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the scope of modern family planning services?
questions.solution:
Correct Ans. C

  • Not Providing adoption services is incorrect as adoption services are provided in modern concept of family planning services.

Incorrect Option: 

Option A.Proper spacing and limiting childbirth: It is a part of the modern concept of family planning services.

Option B. Genetic counseling: It is a part of the modern concept of family planning services.

Option D. Education on parenthood: It is a part of the modern concept of family planning services.

questions.text: To analyze the seasonal fluctuations of a disease in children, two groups were observed. One group was studied from June to July, while the other group, with similar characteristics, was observed from August to September. The appropriate statistical test to compare the data would be:
questions.solution:
Correct Option. A-Chi square:

  • The Chi-square test assesses association or difference between two categorical variables, commonly used to compare frequencies or proportions between groups.
  • In this case, the seasonal variations of a disease in two different groups (June to July group and August to September group) can be compared using the Chi-square test to determine if there is a significant difference in disease occurrence between the two time periods.

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Paired t-test: The paired t-test is used to compare the means of two related groups or to assess the difference between two measurements taken on the same group at different time points.

Option C. Wilcoxon test: The Wilcoxon test compares two independent groups when data aren't normally distributed or when t-test assumptions aren't met. It's for continuous variables, not categorical data or seasonal disease variations.

Option D. ANOVA (Analysis of Variance): ANOVA is a statistical test used to compare means among three or more groups.

questions.text:
Assertion: Topical steroids should not be used in the treatment of viral corneal ulcers.

Reason: Topical steroids can cause increased intraocular pressure

What is the correct option?

choices.text: Both assertion and reasoning are correct and reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both assertion and reasoning are independently correct and reason is not correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is independently a correct statement, but the reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Both assertion and reasoning are independently correct and reason is not correct explanation of the assertion:

  • Both assertion and reasoning are independently correct, but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion: The assertion that topical steroids are contraindicated in viral corneal ulcers is true. This is because topical steroids in such cases can hinder the body's immune response to the infection and results in perforated corneal ulcer..
  • The reasoning stating that topical steroids can cause increased intraocular pressure is also true but does not directly explain the contraindication in viral corneal ulcers.

Incorrect Option:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text:
A research was carried out to evaluate the impact of a treatment for a specific illness. The statistical significance of two comparable studies, A and B, was determined using interventions "X" and "Y" along with a control group, yielding p-values of 0.02 and 0.001 respectively, at a confidence level of 95%. Initial analysis suggests that the findings could be interpreted as:

A. Study B is more precise than study A and intervention Y is more significant compared to Intervention X.

B. Study A is more precise than study B and intervention X is more significant compared to intervention.

C. Both X and Y show a significant variation, but Study B is more significant than Study A.

D. Both study A and B shows a significant variation and both interventions have similar statistical significance.

choices.text: If A, B and C are correct
If A and C are correct
If B and D are correct
If all (A, B, C and D) are correct

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - If A and C are correct:

  • Study A is more precise than Study B: The p-value measures the strength of evidence against the null hypothesis, with a smaller value indicating stronger evidence. Study A's p-value is 0.02, while Study B's is 0.001, indicating Study B's greater precision.

Incorrect Option: 

Option A: If A, B, and C are correct

Option C: If B and D are correct

Option D: If all (A, B, C, and D) are correct

questions.text: In which medical conditions is Tafenoquine used?

choices.text: Treatment of malaria in children <2 years

questions.solution:
Correct Option is A:Tafenoquine is used in the radical cure of Plasmodium infections, which means it is used to eliminate both the blood-stage and dormant liver-stage parasites in patients with malaria. 

Incorrect Options: 

Option B: Prophylaxis of malaria in pregnancy typically involves the use of other antimalarial medications such as chloroquine or mefloquine.

Option C: Severe falciparum malaria is usually treated with intravenous antimalarial medications such as quinine or artesunate.

Option D: Tafenoquine is not approved for use in children under 18 years of age.

questions.text: A study was conducted on two different samples for comparing variation between DBP and Vitamin D. The mean diastolic blood pressure is 110 with standard deviation 11 and the mean vitamin D level is 18 with standard deviation 3. Which of the following statement is true regarding the coefficient of variation (CV)?

choices.text: CV of DBP is more than Vitamin D
CV of Vitamin D is more than DBP
Both DBP and Vitamin D have equal variability
It cannot be ascertained from information provided

questions.solution:
Correct Option B:

  • The coefficient of variation (CV) of DBP is more than Vitamin D.
  • In this scenario, the mean diastolic blood pressure (DBP) is 110 with a standard deviation of 11, and the mean vitamin D level is 18 with a standard deviation of 3.
    • CV of DBP = (11 / 110) * 100 = 10%
    • CV of Vitamin D = (3 / 18) * 100 ≈ 16.67%
  • Comparing the CV values, we can see that the CV of DBP (10%) is lower than the CV of Vitamin D (16.67%). Thus, Option B- CV of Vitamin D is more than that of DBP is correct. 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A. states that the CV of  DBP is more than Vitamin D, which is incorrect based on the calculated CV values.

Option C. suggests that both DBP and Vitamin D have equal variability, which is also incorrect since the CV values differ.

Option D. states that it cannot be ascertained from the information provided, but we can determine the relative variability based on the given data.

questions.text: Under which program does the improvement of labor room quality fall in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - LaQshya:

  • LaQshya is a program for the improvement of the quality of labor rooms in healthcare facilities. It is an initiative of the Government of India that aims to enhance the safety and quality of care provided during childbirth. The program focuses on ensuring respectful maternity care, infection prevention and control, effective communication, and skilled birth attendance.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ayushman Bharat: Ayushman Bharat is a national health protection scheme “in India that aims to provide financial protection and access to quality healthcare to vulnerable population” with “that” focuses on health insurance coverage and primary healthcare services but does not specifically address the improvement of labor room quality.

Option C - Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram: Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram is a government program that promotes safe delivery and postnatal care, it does not specifically address the improvement of labor room quality.

Option D - Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan: Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan focuses on ensuring comprehensive and quality antenatal check-ups but does not specifically focus on improving labor room quality.

questions.text:
Please arrange the following coloured dustbins according to the type of biomedical waste they are meant for.

 


	
		
			
			Column A
			
			
			Column B
			
		
		
			
			
				Catheter
				Torn registration forms
				Expired vaccine
				Antibiotic bottle
			
			
			
			A. Black

			B. Red

			C. Blue

			D. Yellow

			E. White
questions.solution:
Correct Option C -1-B; 2-A; 3-D, 4-C :

  • Catheter: Catheters are are considered sharp waste and should be disposed of in a puncture-resistant blue container.
  • Torn registration forms: Torn registration forms are typically disposed of in black coloured general waste bins.
  • Expired vaccine: Expired vaccines, categorized as pharmaceutical waste, should be disposed of in designated yellow containers for pharmaceutical waste.
  • Antibiotic bottle: Empty antibiotic bottles are generally recyclable and can be disposed of in red bins.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B & D are incorrect matches.

questions.text: Which of the following measures cannot be taken to eliminate confounding factors?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Blinding:

  • Blinding, or masking, prevents participants or researchers from knowing the assigned treatment to minimize bias. While blinding helps in reducing bias, it does not directly address confounding variables.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Randomization: Randomization assigns participants to different groups randomly, balancing confounding variables between groups to reduce their impact on outcomes.

Option C - Restriction: Restriction limits the study population based on certain criteria to control confounding variables by excluding certain groups.

Option D - Matching: Matching selects control subjects with similar characteristics to the study group to control for potential confounders.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about tedizolid?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tedizolid is active against gram-positive organisms:

  • Tedizolid is an antibiotic that belongs to the oxazolidinone class. It exhibits activity against a wide range of gram-positive bacteria, including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus faecalis (VRE).

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Poor oral bioavailability: Tedizolid has good oral bioavailability, which means it can be effectively absorbed when taken orally.

Option C - Active against anaerobes: Tedizolid primarily targets gram-positive organisms and does not have significant activity against anaerobes.

Option D - Causes peripheral neuropathy: Peripheral neuropathy is not a known adverse effect of tedizolid.

questions.text:
In India, cause of death is noted by:


	Sample registration system
	Census
	Death declaration & medical certificate
	Lay reporting
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1, 3, and 4 are correct:

  • In India, the cause of death is noted through the Sample Registration System (SRS), death declaration & medical certificate, and lay reporting methods. The SRS is conducted by the Registrar General of India, collecting data through verbal autopsy. Death declaration involves issuing a medical certificate by a qualified practitioner, while lay reporting gathers information from non-medical personnel.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A -2 & 4 are correct: States options 2 and 4 are correct, which is inaccurate as the Census method is not involved in noting causes of death in India.

Option B -1& 3 are correct: Claims options 1 and 3 are correct, overlooking the relevance of option 4, which involves lay reporting.

Option D -1,2,3 & 4 are correct: Asserts that all options are correct, including option 2, which is not applicable to noting the cause of death in India.

questions.text: Calculate the infant mortality rate of a town with a population of 20,000, based on the following data: In a year, there were a total of 456 births, out of which 56 were stillborn. The total number of deaths was 247, with 56 deaths occurring within 28 days of life, and an additional 34 deaths occurring after 28 days but before completing the first birthday. Calculate the infant mortality rate of the area?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 225:

  • Calculation of Infant Mortality Rate (IMR):
    • Total population: 20,000
    • Total live births: 456
    • Total deaths: 247
    • Deaths within 28 days of life(Neonatal deaths): 56
    • Deaths after 28 days but before completing the first birthday(Number of Post- Neonatal Deaths): 34
  • To calculate the IMR:
    • IMR = (Total infant deaths / Total live births) x 1,000
    • Total Live Births=Total Births−Still born Births=456−56=400
    • Total Infant Deaths=Number of Neonatal Deaths + Number of Post-Neonatal Deaths=56+34=90
    • IMR = 90 / 400 x 1,000
    • IMR ≈ 225
  • Therefore, the infant mortality rate of the area is approximately 225 per 1,000 live births.

 

Incorrect Options: 

  • Option A, B & D are incorrect: 197 - Does not match the calculated infant mortality rate.

questions.text:
SGLT-2 inhibitors are recently used for type -2 diabetes mellitus. Which of the following are the rare but serious side effects?

1. Ketoacidosis

2. Urosepsis

3. Fournier gangrene

4. Angioedema
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1, 2 & 3 are correct:

SGLT-2 inhibitors are a class of medications used for the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus. While they are generally safe and well-tolerated, there are rare but serious side effects associated with their use.

1. Ketoacidosis: Ketoacidosis is a potentially life-threatening condition characterized by high levels of ketones in the blood. It is a rare side effect of SGLT-2 inhibitors but can occur. Patients using SGLT-2 inhibitors should be aware of the symptoms of ketoacidosis, such as excessive thirst, frequent urination, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and fruity-smelling breath.

2. Urosepsis: Urosepsis refers to a severe infection that originates from the urinary tract and spreads to the bloodstream. While urosepsis is a rare side effect, there have been reports of an increased risk of urinary tract infections (UTIs) with the use of SGLT-2 inhibitors. If a UTI is not promptly treated, it can progress to urosepsis.

3. Fournier gangrene: Fournier gangrene is a rare but serious infection of the genital and perineal area. Although extremely rare, there have been reports of Fournier gangrene associated with the use of SGLT-2 inhibitors. Patients should be aware of symptoms such as severe pain, swelling, or redness in the genital or perineal area and seek immediate medical attention if these symptoms occur.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 1, 2 & 4 are correct: While options 1 and 2 are correct, option 4 (Angioedema) is not a known rare but serious side effect of SGLT-2 inhibitors. Angioedema is more commonly associated with other classes of medications, such as ACE inhibitors.

Option C - Only 4 is correct: Option 4 (Angioedema) is not a known rare but serious side effect of SGLT-2 inhibitors. Therefore, this option is not accurate.

Option D - All are correct: While options 1 and 2 are correct, option 3 (Fournier gangrene) is also a rare but serious side effect associated with the use of SGLT-2 inhibitors. Therefore, this option is not accurate.

questions.text: What is the mainstay of management for a patient diagnosed with dengue and presenting with warning signs?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - IV Fluids:

  • When treating a patient with dengue who has warning signs, the cornerstone of treatment is intravenous (IV) fluids. Dengue is a viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes, and patients with warning signs may experience plasma leakage and dehydration. IV fluids are essential to maintain adequate hydration and prevent complications associated with fluid loss.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Options B - Platelets: While platelet transfusion may be necessary in severe cases of dengue with low platelet counts (thrombocytopenia), it is not the cornerstone of treatment for patients with warning signs.

Option C - Cryoglobulins: They are not directly related to the treatment of dengue with warning signs.

Option D - FFP (Fresh Frozen Plasma): FFP is used to manage bleeding disorders or coagulation abnormalities. However, it is not the primary treatment for dengue with warning signs, which focuses on fluid management.

questions.text: Single breath nitrogen method is used for measuring _____________
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Anatomical dead space volume:

  • The single breath nitrogen test, aka fowler’s method is used to estimate anatomical dead space. It involves inhaling pure oxygen and then exhaling slowly and steadily.
  • The alveolar oxygen is mixed with the nitrogen whereas the air in the anatomical dead space is free of nitrogen containing only oxygen thus measuring the anatomical dead space.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Physiological dead space volume: Bohr’s method is used to measure physiological dead space volume.

Option B - Residual Volume: It is calculated by multiple breath nitrogen washout method.

Option C - Tidal volume: It can be calculated by using a spirometer.

questions.text: What is the pathogen that is transmitted by the vector?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Orientia tsutsugamushi:

  • The pathogen transmitted by the vector is Orientia tsutsugamushi. It is the causative agent of scrub typhus, a disease transmitted to humans through the bite of infected chiggers (larval stage of mites). Scrub typhus is commonly found in rural areas of Asia, including regions of Japan, China, South Korea, and Southeast Asia.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Options A - Kyasanur forest disease virus: This virus is transmitted by ticks and causes Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD), a viral hemorrhagic fever primarily found in India.

Option C - Chandipura virus: This virus is transmitted by sandflies and is associated with outbreaks of encephalitis in certain regions of India.

Option D - Anaplasma phagocytophilia: This bacterium is transmitted by ticks and causes Anaplasmosis, a tick-borne infectious disease.

questions.text: Which hormone is specifically produced by the adrenal gland but not by the ovaries in females?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D. DHEA-S (Dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate): DHEA-S is produced predominantly by the adrenal glands. The sulfation of DHEA to DHEA-S occurs mainly in the adrenal glands, and it is not produced by the ovaries.

Incorrect Option:

Option A. Progesterone: Progesterone is produced by both the adrenal glands and the ovaries (primarily by the corpus luteum during the menstrual cycle and by the placenta during pregnancy).

Option B. DHEA (Dehydroepiandrosterone): DHEA is produced by both the adrenal glands and the ovaries.

Option C. Estrogen: Estrogen is produced by both the adrenal glands and the ovaries (primarily by the ovarian follicles, corpus luteum, and placenta).

questions.text: For which of the following conditions is mass drug administration not performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Vitamin A deficiency:

  • Vitamin A deficiency is primarily addressed through nutritional interventions, such as improving dietary intake and providing Vitamin A supplements. MDA involves the large-scale administration of specific medications to treat or prevent certain infectious diseases, but it is not used for addressing nutritional deficiencies like Vitamin A.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Malaria: In Malaria Mass drug administration is commonly used for the treatment and control of malaria transmittion.

Option C - Scabies: Scabies Mass drug administration is sometimes employed in the control of scabies, especially in communities or institutions with high rates of infestation. 

Option D - Filariasis: Filariasis Mass drug administration is a key strategy for the elimination and control of lymphatic filariasis, a parasitic disease transmitted by mosquitoes.

questions.text: A bank employee suffering from depression came to AIIMS OPD. He was started on Escitalopram. Which of these adverse effects cannot be explained with escitalopram?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Sialorrhea:

  • Sialorrhea (excessive salivation) cannot be explained with escitalopram.

  • Escitalopram is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) commonly used for the treatment of depression and anxiety disorders. SSRI's can produce decreased saliva production and dryness of the mouth. Therefore sialorrhea would not be explained by escitalopram use..

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Vivid dreams: Vivid dreams or increased dreaming can be a side effect of escitalopram and other SSRIs. Many individuals experience changes in dreaming patterns, such as more intense or vivid dreams, while taking these medications.

Option C - Anorgasmia: Anorgasmia refers to the difficulty or inability to achieve orgasm. It is a recognized side effect of SSRIs, including escitalopram. SSRIs can interfere with sexual function and may cause sexual side effects such as decreased libido, delayed ejaculation, or difficulty reaching orgasm.

Option D - Nausea: Nausea is a common side effect of escitalopram and other SSRIs, especially during the initial stages of treatment. It may occur in some individuals but usually improves over time or with dose adjustments.

questions.text: Where do the afferent fibers from baroreceptors, responsible for blood pressure regulation, go to?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C. Nucleus Tractus Solitarius: The Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (NTS) is a nucleus in the medulla oblongata that serves as the primary site for receiving afferent signals from baroreceptors. Baroreceptors, located in the walls of the carotid sinus and aortic arch, sense changes in blood pressure. Afferent fibers from these baroreceptors transmit signals to the NTS, which plays a vital role in regulating blood pressure by modulating autonomic outputs.

Incorrect Option:

Option A. Nucleus Ambiguous: The Nucleus Ambiguus is a motor nucleus in the medulla oblongata that primarily innervates the muscles involved in swallowing and phonation. It is not directly involved in receiving afferent signals from baroreceptors for blood pressure control.

Option B. Rostral-Ventro Lateral Medulla: The Rostral-Ventro Lateral Medulla (RVLM) is a region in the medulla oblongata that plays a crucial role in the regulation of sympathetic outflow and blood pressure. It is involved in the efferent pathway for blood pressure control, but it does not directly receive afferent signals from baroreceptors.

Option D. Caudal Ventrolateral Medulla: The Caudal Ventrolateral Medulla (CVLM) is a region in the medulla oblongata involved in the regulation of sympathetic outflow and blood pressure. It primarily serves as an inhibitory center, tonically suppressing sympathetic activity. It is not directly involved in receiving afferent signals from baroreceptors.

questions.text: Which mechanism is responsible for the detachment of the myosin head from actin?

choices.text: Entry of calcium into the sarcoplasmic reticulum

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Binding of ATP:

  • The detachment of the myosin head from actin occurs when ATP (adenosine triphosphate) binds to the myosin head. This binding causes a conformational change in the myosin molecule, leading to the release of myosin from actin.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Entry of calcium into sarcoplasmic reticulum: The entry of calcium play a crucial role in initiating muscle contraction by binding to troponin, which leads to the exposure of myosin-binding sites on actin.

Option C - Change in troponin C configuration: This process is responsible for the attachment of the actin-myosin during muscle contraction by uncoiling the troponin I from the tropomysoin.

Option D - Release of ADP and Pi: The release of ADP (adenosine diphosphate) and inorganic phosphate (Pi) occurs after the myosin head has formed a cross-bridge with actin and undergone a power stroke.

questions.text: What would be the appropriate treatment for a 5-year-old boy who had received a complete course of rabies vaccine in December 2018, but was bitten on the toe by his fully vaccinated pet dog in November 2019, resulting in bleeding at the bite site?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 2 doses of vaccine on Day 0 & 3:

  • The boy and the dog have a history of rabies vaccination, lowering the risk of transmission.
  • Administering 2 doses of rabies vaccine on Day 0 and Day 3 provides additional protection and covers potential immunity gaps.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - No treatment: No treatment may leave gaps in protection despite previous vaccinations.

Option C - 5 doses of vaccine with Immunoglobulin: Immunoglobulin is unnecessary as the dog is fully vaccinated.

Option D - 5 doses of vaccine: 5 doses are excessive given the circumstances.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about the management of a nurse who experienced an accidental needle prick from an HIV-infected needle?

choices.text: Zidovudine is used as monotherapy in post exposure prophylaxis
Washing hands with soap and water is advised
Baseline viral markers of healthcare personnel should be done at the time of prick
Follow up viral markers of healthcare personnel should be measure at 6 weeks
Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz for a period of 4 weeks

questions.solution:
Correct Option is A: False: Zidovudine is not used as monotherapy in post-exposure prophylaxis.

  • Zidovudine (also known as AZT) is not used as monotherapy in post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) for HIV. PEP typically involves using a combination of antiretroviral drugs to reduce the risk of HIV transmission after an accidental exposure. Zidovudine is commonly used as part of a multi-drug regimen in PEP protocols.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Washing hands with soap and water is advised after an accidental needle prick to minimize the risk of infection.

Option C: Baseline viral markers of healthcare personnel should be done at the time of the needle prick to establish their current HIV status.

Option D: Follow-up viral markers of healthcare personnel should be measured at 6 weeks after the needle prick to monitor for any possible seroconversion or HIV infection.

Option E: Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz is a commonly used combination of antiretroviral drugs for post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP). This combination is typically taken for a period of 4 weeks to reduce the risk of HIV transmission.

questions.text: What is the most accurate method to measure the temperature of a soldier brought to the ER from Siachen, in order to rule out hypothermia in a limited resource setting?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Rectal:

  • The rectal temperature is representative of the temperature at the core of the body and varies least with changes in environmental temperature.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Variations of temperature in these areas are usually associated with extreme environment.

questions.text: A polysaccharide vaccine against Streptococcus pneumoniae has 23 serotypes. In which of the following patients is this vaccine most beneficial ?

choices.text: A patient with sickle cell disease
A patient with recurrent otitis media

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Sickle cell disease:

  • Sickle cell patients are prone to severe infections due to spleen issues.
  • Recommended to prevent pneumococcal infections with the 23-valent polysaccharide vaccine.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - A child < 2 years: Children under 2 already receive routine pneumococcal vaccination.

Option C - A patient with cystic fibrosis: Polysaccharide vaccine may not be optimal for immunocompromised patients like those with cystic fibrosis.

Option D - Option D: A patient with recurrent otitis media: Polysaccharide vaccine may not target specific serotypes causing otitis media.

questions.text: Which hormone among the following does not exert its effects on the pancreas?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Gastrin:

  • This option suggests that gastrin does not act on the pancreas. However, gastrin does have an indirect effect on the pancreas. Gastrin is released by the stomach in response to the presence of food and stimulates the secretion of gastric acid. The release of gastric acid can indirectly affect pancreatic function by modulating the release of other hormones involved in pancreatic secretion.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Secretin: Secretin is a hormone that acts on the pancreas. It is released by the duodenum in response to low pH in the stomach. Secretin stimulates the pancreas to secrete bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice, which helps neutralize the acidic chyme entering the small intestine.

Option C - Cholecystokinin: Cholecystokinin (CCK) is a hormone that acts on the pancreas. It is released by the duodenum in response to the presence of fatty acids and amino acids. CCK stimulates the secretion of pancreatic enzymes, such as lipase and amylase, to aid in the digestion of fats and carbohydrates.

Option D - GIP (Glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide): GIP is a hormone that acts on the pancreas. It is released by the small intestine in response to the ingestion of glucose and fatty acids. GIP stimulates the release of insulin from pancreatic beta cells, which helps regulate blood glucose levels.

questions.text: What is the ideal dietary requirement for a patient with end-stage renal disease (stage 5) in terms of renal nutrition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Low volume, high calories:

  • Low volume, high calories: This option is correct. Patients with end-stage renal disease often have limited kidney function and may require dialysis. Due to fluid restrictions and compromised kidney function, their renal feed should be low in volume to minimize fluid intake. However, it should be high in calories to provide adequate energy and nutrition.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - High volume, low calories: High volume feed would increase fluid intake, which may be detrimental for patients with compromised kidney function. Additionally, low calories would not provide sufficient energy and nutrition.

Option C - High volume, high calories: While high calories are important, a high volume may lead to excessive fluid intake.

Option D - Low volume, low calories: Low volume and low calories would not provide adequate nutrition and energy for patients with end-stage renal disease.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding foscarnet is false?

choices.text: It is used for resistant CMV
It is activated by viral thymidine kinase
Regular monitoring of serum electrolytes is required

questions.solution:
Correct Option is C: It is activated by viral thymidine kinase:

  • Foscarnet is an antiviral medication used for the treatment of certain viral infections, including resistant cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections. It works by directly inhibiting viral DNA polymerase without requiring activation by viral thymidine kinase. Therefore, option C is incorrect.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: It is used for resistant CMV: Foscarnet is indicated for the treatment of CMV retinitis in immunocompromised patients, particularly those who have failed or are intolerant to ganciclovir therapy.

Option B: Renal toxicity is seen: Foscarnet can cause renal toxicity, including electrolyte imbalances, impaired renal function, and nephrotoxicity. Regular monitoring of renal function and serum electrolytes is necessary during foscarnet therapy.

Option D: Regular monitoring of serum electrolytes is required: As mentioned above, foscarnet can cause electrolyte imbalances, so regular monitoring of serum electrolytes, including calcium, magnesium, potassium, and phosphate, is important.

Option E: It can cause genital ulceration: Foscarnet has been associated with the development of genital ulcerations, which can be a side effect of the medication.

questions.text: What is the primary function of acetylcholine in the nervous system?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Inducing muscle contraction:

  • Acetylcholine is a neurotransmitter that plays a crucial role in the nervous system, particularly in the transmission of signals between nerve cells and in the communication between nerves and muscles. One of its primary functions is to stimulate muscle contraction by transmitting signals across the neuromuscular junction. Upon release from nerve endings, acetylcholine binds to receptors on muscle cells, leading to the generation of an action potential and ultimately causing muscle contraction.
  • Therefore, option (a) "Inducing muscle contraction" is the correct choice.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Inhibiting neurotransmission: Acetylcholine generally acts as an excitatory neurotransmitter in the nervous system, promoting the transmission of nerve impulses rather than inhibiting it.

Option C - Promoting bone growth: While acetylcholine receptors are present in bone cells, there is no evidence to suggest that acetylcholine plays a significant role in promoting bone growth.

Option  D - Regulating blood sugar levels: Acetylcholine does not directly regulate blood sugar levels. Insulin and glucagon, produced by the pancreas, are the primary hormones involved in blood sugar regulation.

questions.text: Mark the TRUE statements:

choices.text: Efferent arteriolar constriction decreases renal blood flow
Mild contraction of efferent arteriole decreases GFR

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Efferent arteriolar constriction decreases renal blood flow:

  • This statement is true. Constriction of the efferent arteriole leads to a decrease in renal blood flow. This constriction increases the resistance to blood flow, causing a reduction in blood flow to the kidneys.

 

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Efferent arteriole dilation decreases RBF: This statement is incorrect. Efferent arteriole dilation will result in increased renal plasma flow.

Option B - Afferent arteriole constriction increases GFR: This statement is incorrect. Afferent arteriole constriction leads to decrease in plasma flow resulting in decreased capillary hydrostatic pressure and reduced GFR.

Option D - Mild constriction of the efferent arteriole decreases GFR: This statement is incorrect. Mild constriction leads to less reduction in RPF. It may decrease to 500 ml. Due to the mild constriction, the plasma cannot exit the capillary easily, leading to accumulation of plasma when the second 500 ml arrives in the next minute. The subsequent 500 ml pushes the first 500 ml. Thus, in steady-state conditions, the total volume of plasma present at the capillary is approximately 1000 ml, i.e., higher than normal. This leads to a high hydrostatic pressure, which in turn leads to increased GFR.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the reduction of activation energy?

choices.text: Stability of transition state is reduced
It depends upon complementarity of active site of enzyme and substrate
Conformational change may occur at the active site of enzyme at the time of binding to substrate

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Stability of the transition state is reduced: This statement is incorrect. In reality, reducing the activation energy involves stabilizing the transition state rather than reducing its stability. This stabilization makes it easier for the reactants to overcome the energy barrier and proceed with the reaction.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Gf is lowered: This statement is correct. Reducing the activation energy involves lowering the Gibbs free energy of the transition state. By lowering the activation energy, the reaction becomes more favorable, and the transition state is easier to reach.

Option C - It depends upon complementarity of the active site of the enzyme and substrate: This statement is correct. Enzymes catalyze reactions by providing a specific active site that is complementary to the substrate. The complementarity allows for optimal binding and orientation of the substrate, which lowers the activation energy required for the reaction to occur.

Option D - Conformational change may occur at the active site of the enzyme at the time of binding to the substrate: This statement is correct. Enzymes often undergo conformational changes upon binding to the substrate. These changes can help to stabilize the transition state or induce strain in the substrate, making the reaction more favorable and lowering the activation energy.

questions.text: Which indicator is suitable for measuring the total amount of body water?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Tritium:

  • Tritium oxide , also known as hydrogen-3, is a radioactive isotope of hydrogen. It can be used as an indicator to measure total body water because it is freely permeable to capillary and cell membrane. When tritiated water (water containing tritium) is ingested or injected into the body, it distributes uniformly throughout the total body water compartment. By measuring the concentration of tritium in body fluids, researchers can estimate the total body water content.
  • Other indicators used for measuring TBW deuterium oxide and aminopyrine,

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Evans blue: Evans blue is a dye that is commonly used to measure plasma volume.

Option C and D: Mannitol and sucrose are used to measure extracellular fluid volume.

questions.text: What is the term used to refer to the provision in the Mental Health Care Act 2017, which grants a patient the right to select their caregiver and determine their future treatment plan?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D. Advance directive

Under the Mental Health Care Act 2017, the provision that grants a patient the right to choose their caretaker and make decisions about their future course of treatment is known as an advance directive. An advance directive is a legal document that allows individuals to express their preferences and instructions regarding their medical treatment, including mental health treatment, in case they become unable to make decisions in the future. It enables patients to have autonomy and control over their treatment choices and ensures that their wishes are respected.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Treatment directive: This term is not commonly used in the context of the Mental Health Care Act 2017 or mental health legislation.

Option B. Mental will: This term is not recognized and is not commonly used in the field of mental health legislation.

Option C. Future directive: Although similar in meaning to an advance directive, the specific term "future directive" is not commonly used in the context of the Mental Health Care Act 2017 or mental health legislation in general.

questions.text: Which statement most accurately characterizes paradoxical suicide?

choices.text: Suicide occurring at the time when the patient starts to recover
Suicide after taking low dose of drug

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: Suicide occurring at the time when the patient starts to recover.

Paradoxical suicide refers to a phenomenon where individuals take their own lives at a time when they appear to be improving or showing signs of recovery from a mental health condition. It is characterized by a sudden and unexpected act of suicide despite the apparent improvement in the person's mental state or circumstances.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Suicide after taking a low dose of drug: This does not describe paradoxical suicide specifically. The dosage of the drug is not a defining factor in paradoxical suicide.

Option C: Accidental completion of suicide: Paradoxical suicide is not accidental but rather a deliberate act.

Option D: None of the above: This is an incorrect option as option A accurately describes paradoxical suicide.

questions.text: What would be the score on the insight scale for a patient who attributes their mental distress to the summer season?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B The insight scale is used to assess a patient's awareness or understanding of their own mental illness. A score of 3 on the insight scale indicates "Insight present but overvalued ideation." Patient recognizes that there is something wrong with them mentally but attributes it to an external factor (the summer season). This suggests that the patient has some insight into their condition, but their understanding may be influenced by overvalued ideas or beliefs.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A suggests "Slight awareness of illness." This would not be an appropriate score as the patient demonstrates more than slight awareness by attributing their mental state to the summer season.

Option C suggests "Insight present but not consistent." This would also not be an appropriate score as the patient's insight is consistent, albeit influenced by overvalued ideation.

Option D suggests "Good insight." This would not be an appropriate score as the patient's insight is influenced by overvalued ideas, indicating a less than optimal level of insight.

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effects is the least probable in a patient prescribed with escitalopram?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Sialorrhea:

  • Sialorrhea refers to excessive salivation or drooling, and it is not commonly associated with the use of escitalopram. Sialorrhea, or excessive salivation, is not typically associated with the use of escitalopram. Other medications or medical conditions may be more commonly linked to this side effect.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Nausea: Nausea is a common side effect of escitalopram and can occur during the initial stages of treatment. It usually subsides over time.

Option B - Vivid dreams: Escitalopram can cause changes in dream patterns, including vivid dreams. This is a relatively common side effect.

Option C - Anorgasmia: Anorgasmia refers to the difficulty or inability to achieve orgasm. It is a known side effect of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) such as escitalopram.

questions.text: What should be done if a patient with anorexia nervosa follows the recommended diet chart but shows no weight change after one week?

choices.text: Observe the patient for 2 hours post meal
Ask the psychiatrist to prescribe anti-anxiety medication
Increase the calories from 1500 to 2000 in her diet

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Observe the patient for 2 hours post meal:

  • In the case of a patient with anorexia nervosa who is following a prescribed diet chart but not experiencing weight changes after one week, it is important to monitor the patient closely for a period after meals. This observation allows healthcare providers to assess the patient's behaviour, including any signs of purging or excessive exercise that may be affecting their weight.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Asking the psychiatrist to prescribe anti-anxiety medication: While anxiety may be a common comorbidity in anorexia nervosa, it is not the appropriate first step in addressing the lack of weight change. Anxiety medication alone does not directly address the issue of weight gain, and it is essential to rule out other factors before considering medication options.

Option C - Increasing the calories from 1500 to 2000 in her diet: Increasing calorie intake without understanding the underlying cause of the lack of weight change may not be the most appropriate step. It is important to assess the patient's behaviour and rule out any compensatory behaviours or medical factors that may be affecting weight before making changes to the diet plan.

Option D - Increasing water intake: While adequate hydration is important for overall health, increasing water intake alone is unlikely to address the lack of weight change in this scenario. It is crucial to evaluate the patient comprehensively and focus on potential behavioural factors or medical conditions that may be impacting weight.

questions.text: For the diagnosis of all lung carcinomas, a thorax CECT is necessary. However, in which of the following scenarios is MRI considered beneficial?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option is D. Pancoast tumor.

Pancoast tumor, also known as superior sulcus tumor, is a type of lung cancer that occurs in the upper part of the lung, typically involving the lung apex, adjacent chest wall, and nearby structures. This type of tumor is often associated with specific symptoms such as shoulder pain, arm weakness, and Horner's syndrome (a group of symptoms caused by damage to the sympathetic nerves).

In the case of Pancoast tumor, MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) is useful for evaluation and diagnosis. MRI provides detailed images of soft tissues and can help visualize the extent of tumor involvement in the chest wall, surrounding structures, and nerves. It helps in determining the local spread and involvement of adjacent structures, aiding in treatment planning.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A. Small cell lung carcinoma: CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography) of the thorax is the preferred imaging modality for evaluating small cell lung carcinoma, as it provides detailed information about the tumor size, location, and potential metastasis.

Option B. Adenocarcinoma: CECT thorax is commonly used for the diagnosis of adenocarcinoma, as it helps in assessing the tumor size, location, lymph node involvement, and distant metastasis.

OptionC. Carcinoid: CECT thorax is the primary imaging modality used for evaluating carcinoid tumors, as it aids in determining the tumor location, size, and potential metastasis.

questions.text: The given USG of lung shows:
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option is B. Sea shore sign.

The Sea shore sign is seen on ultrasound imaging of the lung. It refers to the appearance of a wavy, irregular border between the aerated lung and the fluid-filled or consolidated lung tissue. This sign is observed in the context of pulmonary edema or consolidation.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Stratosphere sign: This is not a recognized sign in lung ultrasound imaging.

  • Also known as barcode sign.
  • If lung sliding is absent, it will appear on the M-mode images as uniform horizontal straight lines known as the stratosphere sign or the barcode sign

Option C. Troposphere sign: This is not a recognized sign in lung ultrasound imaging.

  • There is nothing like that

Option D. Mirror image artifact: This refers to an artifact where a structure appears duplicated or mirrored in the ultrasound image, and it is not specific to lung imaging.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding amyloidosis?

choices.text: SAA forms amyloid in multiple myeloma
On Congo red staining, amyloid shows apple green birefringence
In AL type amyloid is most commonly formed from kappa chain
β2 - macroglobulin forms amyloid in systemic senile amyloidosis

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - On Congo red staining, amyloid shows apple green birefringence:

  • Congo red, when used in conjunction with polarized light microscopy, produces a characteristic apple green birefringence in amyloid deposits.
  • This staining property is a key diagnostic feature of amyloidosis and helps differentiate amyloid deposits from other substances.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - SAA forms amyloid in multiple myeloma: In multiple myeloma, amyloidosis is usually associated with the deposition of immunoglobulin light chains, specifically the lambda chain, known as AL amyloidosis.

Option C - In AL type amyloid is most commonly formed from kappa chain: In AL amyloidosis, the amyloid fibrils are most commonly formed from the lambda chain.

Option D - β2-macroglobulin forms amyloid in systemic senile amyloidosis: Systemic senile amyloidosis is most commonly associated with the deposition of amyloid fibrils derived from transthyretin.
